review_title: Don't do graduate school, folks...unless you like pain.
job_title: Graduate Student in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Probably the best and most diverse place to do research...in the world.  There are tons of resources.
The weather is also probably the best...in the world.  And the campus is lovely.
I didn't encounter any issues with egos, even with the professors here.  There are always a few bad eggs, but most of the people are very kind and friendly.
cons:
No social scene.  Doesn't matter even if you try to create a social circle, because nobody else does.
I wouldn't say everyone here is a genius, certainly very smart and very diligent.  I suspect most of the best students and potential professors go out into the real world.
High risk, low reward research.  Same standard problems encountered in any graduate project: it's hard for professors/students to come up with new influential ideas all the time, and so not all projects have a pay off.  Likewise the publish or perish attitude forces professors to engage in low quality or uninteresting research simply to get a paper.

job_title: Associate Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Lots of truly exciting and wonderful research is taking place at Stanford. It's always a pleasure to interact with faculty and students who making substantial contributions to their fields. While the pay is far below industry, it is well above what you'd earn at "true" non-profit operation. In development (fundraising), there are many career paths, and with networking and hard work, you can attain promotions over time. There are many working parents and commuters in the office, and as such, management is generally quite understanding about the need for a flexible schedule-- eg adjusted hours, working from home, taking time to go to doctors' appts during the day, etc. That's a rarity that I know many of my coworkers appreciate.
cons: The development office is quite large and slow moving. If you're looking to share and implement new ideas, take on challenging side projects, or simply be promoted, be prepared for at least some measure of disappointment. Stanford development does not pay enough to attract and keep top talent, nor are they particularly welcoming of newcomers. There is a lot of weight placed on "loyalty" and years of service, which means usually the mediocre talent sticks around, while the best talent goes elsewhere. There are, of course, exceptions. For better or for worse, Stanford seems to have a difficult time terminating employees who are clearly below average, while also struggling to adequately promote or reward employees who are clearly far above average, outstanding.

review_title: Join Stanford -- it's a great place to work
pros: (1) Environment -- physically, you have space to enjoy the outdoors and take in the beautiful campus.  On another level, you are working in an environment where cutting-edge research/knowledge is produced and shared, making what you do all that more meaningful (2) Work life balance -- by 5pm, you are done and no need to worry about work when you get home. (3) Benefits -- you have free use of the gym and libraries, even for your spouse. There is a lot of support to help you maintain balance in your life, whether it is to be more healthy, or to take care of your aging parents.  You also have a set amount of money to spend for your own career development (roughly $800/year). (4) People -- in the academic environment, people are more laid back than the corporate world.
cons: Bureaucracy -- it can take a while to navigate the various sytems (especially financial systems) to accomplish what you want to do.  It at times can feel like I work for the government as things churn much slower than would be at a for-profit corporation.  Many of the systems also don't integrate well, and much productive time is lost waiting for the data to be produced from online queries.

They will showcase  you and your exciting work to their private donnors, then they will take the money from the donnors. So If you are at a phase in your carreer that you can use the recognition of the school, then it is good to plan on working there to use their strongest advantage (name brand) . review_title: Great atmosphere to work in with a lot of benefits, but as with any place there are drawbacks.
job_title: Student Services Officer in Stanford, CA
pros: The campus is beautiful and there are plenty of opportunities to take advantage of such as lectures, events, and ways to network with colleagues. The students are amazing and it's always a pleasure to work with them. There are a lot of hard-working individuals who keep the university moving forward.
cons: I came from a state school prior to working at Stanford, so the decentralized structure took some getting used to. Student services positions are more administrative in nature with less of a focus on program or student development. There isn't much room for growth within these roles and managers do not necessarily know how to manage. Stanford is a hierarchical organization which can make it difficult to make changes within a department, especially, if the manager has been there a long time. I don't' get the sense that staff are treated as professionals or appreciated by the university. Nor does it feel like the staff have a voice. I think if I were in a different point in my career (late career) Stanford would be a good place to work.

review_title: Great place to work, Strong benefits, and World-class institution
job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Stanford, CA
pros:
As a staff employee in a research lab, I was blessed to work some truly intelligent people!  The atmosphere was great and the learning opportunities never stopped!

It was great to be able to attend so many seminars to continue my learning.  There was always an interesting talk to attend, given by some of the world's most intelligent and hardworking people!
cons:
As a Staff Engineer, there is little room for career growth, in terms of moving up the ladder.  Despite having great recommendations and my manager's full recommendation, HR refused a promotion for me from the lower of two possible R&D Engineer classifications to the higher because I didn't have any people reporting to me.  This is generally impossible in a lab environment because our overall lab size was 10-12 members total, including the two Staff Engineers.  As such, there is no need to have a managerial hierarchy.  This can limit one's ability to show career growth on their resume, but if you are focused on learning a lot and working with intelligent people, this quickly becomes an afterthought.

Most research employees are underpaid, relative to industry standards, b/c it is academia, where money isn't as abundant as in industry.  As such, you shouldn't take jobs at Stanford if you are trying to get rich, but instead should do it because you enjoy working on cutting-edge research and working with world-renowned people!

review_title: Organizational success is attainable, but management gets in the way.
pros: Great benefits, laid back atmosphere/culture. In the higher-ed realm, the salaries are excellent. For non-IT or non-technical staff, salaries seem to be competitive with private industry. Funding is excellent for current/exciting projects. Great location, lots of amazingly talented employees and faculty.
cons:
IT and technical staff salaries are much lower than in the private sector, and few if any opportunities for bonuses or significant pay raises are available. 

Reportedly, the median employment length is 12 years at Stanford (longer than many of the startups nearby have even existed). That itself isn't a con, but this also means a lot of people are here for a LONG time, and there are plenty of cases where people coast for the end of their career -- ie, the last 10-15 years of it. It's very hard to motivate employees who have a comfortable job that they know they won't get fired from. Thus, execution times for projects or large initiatives can often take much longer than in the private sector.

job_title: Web Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: They know they're not competitive on salary so they try to have great benefits to make up for it.  The place offers a good work/life balance, tuition/childcare programs (work there for five years and your kid gets money to pay tuition at any college), lots of options for health insurance at relatively reasonable prices, continuing education opportunities, and nice touches like free Caltrain passes.  You have to work hard but not too hard.   It's a good, steady job and you know what to expect most days.  It's not saving the world, but it still feels meaningful enough.  Management treats people like adults.
cons: Parking.  Seriously.  Parking on campus sucks.  Most technical jobs have a work @ home option at least some of the time, but you're still probably going to be looking for a parking space three or four days a week.  Biking is an option in good weather, if you're brave enough, or you can take public transit and the free shuttle from Caltrain.  It takes a while to get where you're going, but it's about even compared to a bad parking day.  The other risk is that you might have to interact with actual college students, but it can usually be avoided.

job_title: PhD Student (With Fellowship) in Stanford, CA
pros:
I'm a Phd student in a humanities field, and I like it here a lot.
Great environment, everyone is really bright and interesting!
Grateful for subsidized housing.
I really love my department.  The faculty are inspiring, the other students are positive, and there's a very intellectually curious culture.  We don't have to TA too much, so we can invest in our skills (for example, learn to program).
I've also really appreciated being in Silicon Valley because I have been able to get tech internships in the summer.
cons:
Stanford is full of fascinating people...but we are so silo-ed into our individual departments that it's almost impossible to meet them.  I wish there was more of a grad student community across departments.

Some people will absolutely not get academic jobs, but the department still subtly stigmatizes the non-academic path (not in so many words, but by providing career resources, workshops that presuppose everyone is looking for an academic job).    I wish it was more okay to say that a person is thinking about an industry career.

I will also mention that while most of the students are very promising, a few of them are fairly mediocre, but are allowed to stick around anyway.  I'm not sure this is ultimately a good thing, because they will have a very hard time finding a job.

Finally, I wish we had dental insurance.

pros: Great school in terms of opportunities and namesake.
cons: Ultimately teaching is fairly standard and not exceptional.

review_title: Overall good company to work for!  Administrative Associates are not paid well.
job_title: Administrative Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
-Employee benefits
-Commute Incentives
-Educational Funds
-Beautiful campus
-Great Events
cons:
-Hiring relatives or friends for open positions is very common.  No selection process in place.  In turn, depts end up with inexperienced employees.   
-HR and ELR should do internal audits in departments that do not have an HR Manager present in their building.  You would be surprised how many managers and supervisors are unaware of HR policies and procedures.  
-Employees that have been their 10yrs or more - extremely comfortable individuals, not open to change, sense of self entitlement, seniority.
-Stanford does not like to fire people.   Even though it is clear that the employee is not fit for the position or is not performing to dept's expectations.
-Administrative Associates are not paid well at Stanford.  Managers like to give bonuses or the minimum allowable % for the year.

job_title: Graduate Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: It's one of the top schools in the world.
cons: I don't have cons to report.

pros: It's a great school to attend
cons: Wouldn't trade for anything else

job_title: First Year Mentor in Stanford, CA
pros:
Low time-commitment
Meet new students
Build community
cons: It's hard to think of anything bad about working here.

pros: Best place ever - heart of silicon valley
cons: None, no downsides at all

job_title: PhD Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent students and professors to learn from
cons: Not many cons I could list

job_title: Software Development Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Pays well, good food in area
cons: Not much that I can think of

job_title: Data Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stanford is a Great School

cons: there aren't any that I can think of

job_title: Medical Assistant/Phlebotomist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Always new training to learn something new
cons: Short staff, its always extra work.

pros: wonderful people and exciting projects
cons: lots of red tape for administrators

job_title: Life Science Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Prestige is the main thing.  If you have "Stanford" on your resume, future job opportunities will be more accessible.  It's also a pretty big place, so lots of stuff is going on around you and you can get involved pretty easily.
cons: People are pretty judgemental - not just at Stanford, but all over the city that surrounds it (Palo Alto).  If you're not either born into wealth and comfort or someone who was permitted to join in by virtue of being particularly intellectually talented, expect to feel like an outsider.  It's also a ruthless power-play environment, at least in the area of academic research.  Everyone is pretty cut-throat competitive, so if that's not the game you like to play, perhaps find somewhere else.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Tons of resources made available
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Good professors and courses. Friendly students.
cons: Too expressive, competitive and spread out.

review_title: Choose wisely ......not all labs are created equal
pros: opportunities to collaborate with the best in their field. great weather,  the campus has a beautiful park like setting, within driving distance to Tahoe for skiing
cons: I work in a lab center and the admin staff is horrible. I have never dealt with such a rude bunch of people.  My flat mate works in another and he has nothing but nice things to say about  his the admin staff. He brags to me out how the staff is very caring  and takes care of their members.  He even went to a center arranged outing to a baseball game even though he did not know anything about baseball.   He gets the opportunity to more know alot more people across the entire center  because of the social events while I feel isolated in mine.  I must say that his experience made me realize that one must choose wisely when making a decision to join a lab. Not all lab environments are created equal.

review_title: Great community, relatively low pay for SV
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stanford is a great place to work mostly because of all the perks of being a member of such a large research community.  Lots of interesting events and speakers, etc.  They do offer lots of time off (13.33hrs/mo after your first year) along with three use/lose days per year, and I think another floating day, and the university shuts down for 2 weeks in December.  The retirement matching program is great, begins at 5% matching and goes up to 15%.  Pretty flexible and casual work environment.
cons: The little perks are needed because they don't pay staff a salary that is sufficient for Silicon Valley.  Staff can do the same work at any other SV company and make significantly more.  Faculty and student needs are given significant weight, while staff is usually not given much.  It makes sense to put faculty and students first, but not giving staff sufficient pay leads to bad administrative support for those students and faculty.  Good staff leave for greener pastures outside.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Scientifically speaking it is one of the best places in the word, no doubt. You are working at the cutting-edge of your field. You get to interact with some of the world experts of your field of research. You can attend really interesting scientific talks every week. Scientifically speaking Stanford is very hard to match. Furthermore, your work can have a very big impact as Stanford is very influential. Lots of outside recognition for your work and your degree. Stanford's name really goes a long way. Oh and you get used to seeing last year's Nobel prize winner having lunch in the local cafeteria!
cons: Everyone seems to be really busy, particularly the heads of the research labs who are too busy doing a zillion things. Furthermore, despite the overall nice and sunny country-club feeling this university is a very competitive place where it is very common that graduate students and researchers in general feel very isolated and lonely. I wish research were done in practice in a more collaborative and collegial atmosphere. Furthermore, the Stanford area has become so expensive that graduate students are really having a hard time making ends meet. I used to live in a studio and had to move back to shared housing because I could not afford the rent any more!

pros: Working for a well-regarded institution devoted to public service and knowledge creation is pretty great. The social impact of the work is palpable and the resources available are great. Benefits package for full-time university employees is decent with good retirement contribution (if you contribute 4%, they contribute 5%) after 1 year of employment. The people working here are usually intelligent and friendly. Access to all the speaker events and other academic and cultural events on campus is a huge, huge perk. Very vibrant place to work. Plenty of opportunities for professional development. People can respect your work/life balance if you do a good job of communicating your needs in advance.
cons: It's a huge institution with the requisite bureaucracy. Working in development, in particular, has its fair share of bureaucracy to deal with that sets a hurry-up-and-wait-like pace. Often, the motive for projects remains a mystery due to need-to-know policies regarding donor information, so you gotta be able to trust that your management is setting the right priorities for your team.

pros:
Stanford expresses strong values and provides great benefits.
Reputable institution. 
Provides excellent training and classes.
cons: Managers here are unprofessional and breaks administrative policies because of their power trips. They do not encourage team orientation or positive working environments, instead controls their every move to manipulate situations and gives only very negative feedback. Managers are deceitful and will ruin you if they don't "like" you. Petty and it's a disgrace considering that Stanford is reputable institution. The whole department is walking around on eggshells because no one is allowed to speak with each other or ask any questions. It is hostile and I've witnessed some employees fall so far behind because of their unreasonable amount of work, and see the favored ones who doesn't do much at all. Bad management skills overall!

review_title: Administration cares more about their bottom line than they do about their students
job_title: Ph D Student in Stanford, CA
pros: As a graduate student in the Biosciences, pay is probably one of the highest in the world (although still just enough to get by, don't expect to save much). Also, of course having the name brand on your resume will really help you get jobs after graduating. While the overall administration is chilly to graduate students, individual administrators care deeply and will advocate for students, especially in the Biosciences.
cons: The overall Stanford administration treats graduate students like cattle to be herded here and there. They care very little about the graduate population, despite the fact that there are more graduate students attending Stanford and living on campus than undergrads. There are graduate students in the humanities who are paid so little that they forage for food on campus, and despite a recent spate of grad student suicides, Stanford has effectively cut all support for mental health--students are generally only allowed one appointment at CAPS, and that appointment is used to help the student find off-campus mental health services, which are very few and far between because so many students are seeking mental health treatment in the surrounding areas. They decide whether to treat us like students, children, tenants, or employees whenever it suits them best.

review_title: Great place to work if you come up with earth-shattering science; make your own career advancement opportunities.
pros: Extreme flexibility in research objectives and how to carry them out and in work-life balance.  Access to outstanding equipment, students, and scholars.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Career uncertainty in biotech field is a real problem.  Severe lack of straightforward path to tenure track positions in academia is a bigger problem.  Stanford has been ineffective at helping students and scholars navigate this difficult career environment.  Compensation for post docs is a joke, especially since it is taking longer and longer for post docs to obtain tenure track positions - unrealistic compensation for people who now have to live off a "stipend" while starting a family - but this problem is nationwide. Horrible bureaucracy in Stanford places unrealistic burden on students and post docs - Stanford needs to reevaluate what they are doing.  Parking is very far away from the medical research buildings and parking permits are very expensive for an employer that owns a tremendous amount of land.

review_title: Stanford is a good place to work for but can be improved still
job_title: Communications, Finance and Administration Manager in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford tries hard to be diversified. It provides a lot of internal training for staff's career advancement. The situation of work environment varies from department to department. Most of the departments and schools have very reasonable work environment with fair and understanding management. Stanford's pay scale in general is not bad, and benefits are comparable with some bug companies. Stanford also strives for work life balance for staff and students. The campus is amazingly beautiful, and the university tries their best to discourage personal cars on campus by building a lot of bike only roads. In general, Stanford is a good organization to work for.
cons: The more competitive schools (like medicine and engineering) have more cut-throat environment. Also, because Stanford is a research university, there is always the need for meeting the highest standard of research. Administrators sometimes feel the pressure of being knowledgeable about the most up to date research regulations at all times, which might not be possible all the time. Stanford management is not always transparent in terms of policy and benefit changes.

review_title: Beautiful campus with outdated admin systems, specifically payroll
pros: Campus is stunning. Good variety of interesting events (talks, performances) on campus throughout the year.
cons: If you are non-exempt staff, the payroll software doesn't recognize any difference between the hours you put on your time card and your reported schedule.  I changed my schedule to fill in for a co-worker for a couple of months last year. After I returned to my normal schedule, I put my regular hours on my time card, but I was still being paid for additional hours. This went on for nearly two months until an HR person noticed. It shouldn't require someone looking at a timecard to see that an employee is being paid more than their reported hours. My choices were to write a check to the university for the overpayment, or have a certain amount taken out of several pay checks until the overpayment was settled. I wrote the check; lucky for me that I don't live paycheck to paycheck.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The campus and the weather is wonderful.  There are many activities that are available to the staff and the benefits are very generous.  There is always something exciting going on.  Once you are in the Stanford organization, changing positions between departments is rather easy.
cons:
There is a lot of silly decisions made due to the policial nature of the organization. Since this is a nonprofit organization no one in the administrative side is really accountable for their spending or effectiveness.  This probably accounts for the high cost of tuition.  

The HR department is really ineffective.  The policies protect the staff and the faculty.  Middle managers are always at risk of getting into trouble.  The HR people do not do a good enough job of explaining this at orientation.

Many administrative postions are filled by individuals who are not qualified for their job.  They were hired as assistants and just "grew" into the postion. I was surprised by the lack of professionalism.

review_title: Good job if you're right for it
pros:
- Incredible resources
- Very little "red tape" or bureaucracy compared to other research schools
- Brilliant colleagues, professors
- Great reputation
- Excellent fellowship opportunities
cons:
(These refer to being a graduate research assistant)
- No benefits (at all).
- Extremely low pay; salary is similar to schools like Univ. of Illinois, but with one of the highest costs of living in the country.
- Schools is out to make money off of you; mandatory fees for healthcare *even if you provide your own health insurance*; bleeding sponsoring companies for $70k/year, while students only see $30k.
- Graduate housing is ridiculous; $1200/month for a studio, when the land is free (donated to stanford), the buildings are subsidized (by donors), and presumably taxes are low (b/c it's a nonprofit). Plus, they won't let students out of their leases; they're locking them into this horrible above-market price b/c they didn't know better before they arrived. Seems ridiculous for a university that's supposed to look out for its grad students.

review_title: The ideal on-campus job for busy students
pros: Lots of downtime, especially during the night shift where you're required to stay at the front desk.  This provides plenty of time to do your homework. The work is easy (answering phone calls, checking in/out library materials, shelving books, making spreadsheets etc.).  This library is very small compared to Green Library, so there aren't as many books to shelve and the front desk is rarely crowded. Staff is very accommodating to your class schedule. If you prove to be a good worker, staff will invite you back each quarter.  As a result, I worked here during my entire undergraduate career. I was very satisfied with my pay, and my boss gave me a (small) raise each year.
cons: During the Winter quarter, you have to "shelf read". Basically, you (and all of the other student assistants) go through ALL of the books in the library to make sure each book is shelved in the right place (according to the Library of Congress classification system). This process will typically take the entire quarter to complete.  If you don't have other work to do, it can get pretty boring.

review_title: Stanford has many unique benefits, but little career growth opportunities
pros:
Staff have free access to on campus gyms, courts (including basketball, racquetball and squash), olympic-sized swimming pool and PE classes. There is also a great on-campus bike shop.
Stanford pays you to not drive and gives you free passes on VTA (including trips to Monterrey and Santa Cruz) and Caltrain. 
Staff can check out library books, audit classes and attend the lectures happening all the time on campus. Staff also get training funds that can be used on courses of their own choosing.
Spouses can also get a card giving them access to Stanford facilities. 
Stanford will be your children's tuition at any college - up to half the cost of Stanford's tuition. (Luckily, Stanford has high tuition!) However, you must work for 5 straight years to be eligible.
cons: Salary is below what you can get in industry. There are not many career advancement opportunities. While you audit classes, you cannot take classes for credit. You can also not take the Stanford foreign language classes. (Though you can take the continuing education ones.)

pros: Decent benefits program; especially tuition refund for children of employees.
cons: Highly bureaucratic structure with poor managerial team.  Stanford is a non-profit institution whose primary product is education.  There is an effort to convert institution into a "for-profit" model supposedly for efficiency.  In the process, it is losing creativity, intellectual vitality, and most importantly, it's sense of humanity.  Chasing the political winds, using punitive rather than motivation incentives, and overly focusing on monetary goals are making the institution less prestigious.  It is also ruining the academic culture of exchange and instilling a climate of fear instead.  Founder Mrs. Stanford would be aghast and not recognize her own intentions given how the institution has evolved.

job_title: SoM Staff in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Not as demanding as private sector
Good job security
Some departments are fun to work for (all depends on the people)
cons:
Extremely political and very resistant to change
You may be told what the policy is, but they expect something different from you
Very low salary for the area and raises/bonuses are basically non-existent
Benefits for single (no kids) people are not good at all, they seem to benefit families way more
If you're not married and have no kids it's hard to relate to coworkers making it a bit isolating
Parties, catered food, and happy hours are rare if they happen at all (or you have to plan and fund them yourself)
Definitely felt discriminated against for being young
Working in a cubicle farm is miserable

job_title: Social Science Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: Collaborative work environment, flexible remote schedule, state of the art hardware and software, endless research opportunities, amazing staff and students, and a great opportunity for professional development.
cons: Stanford is a bit of a bubble, so it is quite easy to be "stuck" which can be both good and bag.  Good because you get to work on some amazing projects with brilliant faculty and students, but bad because once you're in a lab or on campus working that becomes your second home basically.  I rarely made it to San Francisco, LA, San Jose, San Diego, or Tahoe unless it was work related.  To each their own though, so if you prioritize getting out of the "bubble" then I imagine you'll fine.  Otherwise, lean in and spend as much time asking as many questions as possible on campus because you'll learn a TON!

pros: Stanford is a great place to work however the school and department you work in can make a big difference. I have worked in two different schools at Stanford and it was a night and day difference. The faculty members you work with can make your life terrible or wonderful.
cons: constantly changing rules and regulations, vague job expectations from managers, parking sucks, HR is terrible, weak middle managers,  upper management always sides with faculty members and not staff. I was once told by my administrative manager " faculty members can do and say whatever they want because they bring money into the school, deal with it you are a staff member and you work for them".

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Amazing colleagues, world class facilities, beautiful location. Stanford is incredible strong in the biological sciences, with a bias towards experimental efforts. The benefits are fantastic, as is the more general social offerings for students and postdocs. The institutions name brings many talented individuals to campus, and also helps with future job prospects
cons: Competitive culture lurks below surface. While the relaxed Californian attitude is clear at Stanford, there are obviously strong competitive forces at work, and despite their prestigious positions, many PIs are poor managers of the talented people they have in their labs. For those in experimental work, the strong focus on high impact work, means that many grad students and postdocs may work on single projects lasting several years with the sole aim of a high impact publication. This means that for those who are not fortunate enough to lad an exciting results, they will be rather empty handed. PIs with big labs assume that not all projects will work, but a fraction will, allowing continued high level output, however, typically at the cost of burning junior trainees.

review_title: Facilitate incredible initiatives, but don't expect to rise quickly
pros: The work is interesting and enjoyable. I make a difference every day to people's education, research or outreach. There is a lot of work to do, and because Stanford is a non-profit there is never enough people to do it, which is great if you want to work hard and be a part of some truly incredible initiatives.
cons: Stanford respects experience over ability. As such the average age of my office is ~40+. As a young professional it can be a shock, especially when you're surrounded by companies that value young people and their perspectives. Don't expect to be promoted quickly, Stanford is hierarchical, and seemingly does not promote from within. Most people I've met have ascended by moving departments within the organization, and there are plenty of organizations to move between.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Stanford, CA
pros: The benefits are fantastic, especially if you are a parent paying for your student's tuition. There is a work/life balance that is honored at Stanford. The community at Stanford is willing to help, there is no real competition or market-based product management. There is a real emphasis on honing your soft skills.
cons: Projects are consensus-based, so projects usually take years to complete. It's difficult to project manage others if you are in the age of 20-35 years old; most of your stakeholders are on average 45 years or older. An obstacle to getting work and projects completed on time is that there is a lot of effort that needs to be made in navigating politics, consensus-building, and being tactful in trying to do your job without people feeling like you are telling them what to do. Lastly, there is little room for advancement in your own organization. To grow, you'll need to strategically get higher position levels by joining another organization in Stanford.

review_title: Comfortable place to work with limited opportunities for advancement
job_title: Clinical Trial Coordinator in Redwood City, CA
pros: The university tries to create an environment that is supportive of employees. Benefits are excellent but the pay  is on the low end for most mid level staff jobs. Many positions are flexible and using alternative transportation is encouraged.
cons: While the university provides opportunities for additional training however actual advancement within a particular position or office are extremely limited. Staff tend to move between departments to advance their career. There is a cap on salary increases if a staff members moves to a higher level position meaning they may be paid less than someone hired from outside the university. The facilities are hit or miss depending on where you are located. Transportation and parking can be very difficult.

pros:
1. Flexible work schedule.  Telecommute is very common on campus and is encouraged in many departments because of limited parking spaces on campus. Stanford pays you $200 each year for not driving. Why drive?
 
2. Great workout facilities.  The campus has gyms, pools, tennis court, any facilities you can think of - all free for staff, faculty and students. You can take exercise classes for $20/quarter.  Take a health survey, you'll get $150. 

3. Descent salary. Stanford offers 4 weeks vacation, 3 days of Paid-Time-Off, and 1 floating holiday each year.  We dont get bonus, but the benefits in general are pretty nice.
cons:
Stanford has limited parking spaces.  Guests often cannot find parking.  Thats why Stanford pays for employees' caltrain pass.  
Working with too many smart people.  Everyone at Stanford is so smart.  Sometimes it's depressing to see what others have achieved.

review_title: Good work/life balance, pace too slow for perfectionists
pros:
Good work/life balance
Flexible work hours
Good salary
Free CalTrain sticker and Clipper card to cover mass transit
Free community shuttle to help get across the campus and the neighboring community
cons:
Things operate on "Stanford" time; what would take days in the outside world can take weeks or months here
Lack of transparency from upper management means lots of secrets and a perpetual feelings of unease
Doing what's right for the org sometimes takes a backseat to not hurting someone's feelings; more damaging in the long run
The department I work in has a policy that prevents working from home; tough for new parents
Parking is tough in some parts of campus, plus you are required to purchase a parking permit

review_title: Great place to work with very smart people
job_title: Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: There are many perks of working at Stanford. The benefits are great. You get to work with the best professionals in the field. There are several plans to keep you healthy and make sure you have a work/life balance.
cons: Stanford is a really big work place. Depending on where you work you might get stuck with a bad human resources person. The HR person for my department was terrible. She assure me and my hiring manager that Stanford was e-verified when it really wasn't. After I was hired we found out that was not the case and I had to leave my position shortly after being hired. Needless to say this was extremely inconvenient and frustrating for all parties involved. While I am sure this is only a particular careless HR person it is important to double check before trusting your HR person.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator I in Stanford, CA
pros: Excellent benefits and retirement package, beautiful campus/town, great co-workers, ample time off. Would highly recommend working here. Very reasonable lateral/small upward movements if you have the background and experience, coupled with being a good worker.
cons: Salary is definitely on the low end of the area for how qualified you need to be to get the job, and the annual raises are typically 1-3% of your income so the Peninsula quickly outpaces your wages. It's truthfully almost better to re-apply to a different department/division every 2 years so you can bump your title/pay grade because the standard annual raises will never match that.

pros: Flexible work hours, great environment, short walk to work and coworkers that inspire me to excellence. The salary that I forgo to work as a research assistant is more than five times what I am paid. The lost salary is more than made up for by external factors such as subsidized housing in one the the greatest places on earth and the above mentioned environmental factors. My daughter has no concept of parents who work (even by professional standards) since we breakup our days to accommodate her and our work schedules.  The compensation package that one would need to offer me to leave is likely far more than anyone would offer, indicative of the value I place on the living environment opposed to monetary compensation.
cons: One day I likely must leave and return to a corporation. By then I may have forgotten the skills of corporate gladiatorial combat.

pros: Some of the brightest minds in the world are here, tackling difficult and timely research questions.
cons:
While individual ("low"-level) administrators tend to be more than excellent, the administrative body as a whole is more fake than any company or university I've ever encountered. On issues of diversity, mental health, benefits, pay, and workers rights, in my four years here, we've gotten nothing but the occasional email from the administration praising itself for its commitment to these issues (even though no such commitment exists). 

If you have the resources to stand on your own two feet throughout rocky times with low pay and little support, then Stanford can definitely be worth it. But the area is so overpriced that unless you are independently well-off, living here can be suffocating. 

I guess this is to Stanford's benefit, since it means you'll be spending all those extra hours working instead of trying to actually enjoy life a little.

review_title: Easy place to do a graduate degree
pros: The location cannot be beat.  Northern California is a place that people move to and do not leave for the rest of their lives. Graduate students here are generally very well funded, especially compared to other universities.  As a private institution, Stanford is not as susceptible to the whims of budget and funding problems.  There is a certain air of pride in the air that whatever Stanford does, it does well. The school of education, where I work, is very good compared to the most of the top ed schools, especially when it comes to funding and support.  Facilities are comparatively good.
cons: Palo Alto itself is a terrible place to live and work.  Obviously each graduate field has its own micro-climate within the university.  The on-campus food is beyond terrible.  There are no good options other than Jamba Juice.  Can't live on that for too long.

review_title: old-fashioned, conservative, and hierarchical. no room for personality here!
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros:
- pay is pretty good once you've moved up through the ranks
- great health insurance options
cons:
- managers are too strict, micromanagey, and inflexible. they treat their employees like children that can't be trusted. 
- raises are minimal
- culture and policies are conservative, old-fashioned, and not progressive, as you would expect from a world-class university
- no opportunities for personal development or work-life balance
- hours are strictly 8-5 with a 1 hour lunch - no flexibility for long-distance commuters
- upper management is dismissive of lower employee's ideas/innovations
- bad managers are allowed to continue their reign of terror
- HR is not there to protect or help you - they only care about upper management

job_title: Student Services Specialist in Stanford, CA
pros: At Stanford, employees are offered incredible benefits, and they offer a variety of programs that improve the employee's experience.
cons: Sometimes, the LEAN culture leads administrators to shoulder greater workloads than one person reasonably can.

review_title: HighWire's a great, comfortable place to work
job_title: Senior Applications Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: highwire has a friendly, relaxed environment, and for the most part, people seem happy to work there.  you can bring your dog to work with you (if it's well-behaved), and that adds to the fun atmosphere.  the absolute best part of working at highwire press is that you are  an employee of *stanford university*, which comes along with a tremendous set of benefits: lots of vacation, great retirement, access to athletics and classes on campus, etc.
cons:
depending on what position you have, the job skills may have limited application outside of the highwire press environment.  however, in 2006 this was changing, so perhaps is better now.
my job requirements did not change dramatically over the time I was there, so it got a little boring, and there is little opportunity to move up in the organization (just because it is so flat anyway).

pros: The people are great; professors are engaging, colleagues are interesting, students are highly motivated. The weather is fantastic, as is the campus (we called it the Palo Alto Country Club). Teaching these undergrads is a delight. Research may be conducted under some of the best conditions in the world. Not a bad place to be a PhD student, indeed...
cons: Alas, while being a doctoral student at Stanford, one is a tenant in a mansion.. The grim realities of the job market should be considered heavily for anyone entering a PhD program, particularly in the social sciences and humanities. This is not Stanford's fault, obviously, but they could do more to arm students for an extra-academic job. Also, the pay is not as high as it seems; the cost of living around Stanford makes the seemingly high stipend borderline insufficient.

job_title: Social Science Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford throws a ton of money into research, after-all it is a research-driven institution. The pay is pretty good if you're an undergraduate, and depending on your pro-activity, you can search and request to work for a grad student or professor that shares your intellectual interests. Most professors and grad students love getting all the help they can get.
cons:
Working as a RA under someone's project can be very boring. Often the beginning of your research career will entail data entry, coding, or something mechanical, which was tedious to me. If you like routine work though then being an RA might be your thing.

 If possible, I encourage prospective RAs to work for someone who shares their intellectual interests and trusts them to contribute your ideas and thoughts into the research process.

review_title: Stanford Computer Resource Consulting is your way to the easy life - if that is your thing.
job_title: Windows/Mac Systems Administrator (Contract) in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Awesome campus, great extracurricular opportunities
- Fun people, low stress and low expectations (if low expectations are your thing)
- Essentially, something of a government job / employment for life feel
cons:
- Low expectations of IT workers and IT services. Outages are common as is poor performance from co-workers
- Your co-workers will be under qualified for their position
- Utilizing new technology or process is deemed a hindrance as it would impact the established level of performance and effort required to provide current services
- Politics and philosophy may guide decision making, rank and file employees input will not be considered

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Full Benefits on the first day of employment at a nice rate of $17.99.40 hours a week . It's a government position that takes place at SLAC. looks good on resume. Stanford small percentages off events and merchandise.Helping spanish speakers get checked in and get guidance while staying at the Stanford Guest House is an indescribable feeling. that to me was the greatest part of my job.
cons: Manager who hires encourages bad habits to the employees who have late seniority. when a new person comes in there are a few five that are up to no good by making the new person feel completely unwelcome. lack of communication and interest to do the job happily and competently. two make it clear from the first few days what the new person will be put through because they all worked hard for their permanent position. one of the two says all the mean things are done as their way of hazing the newbies. the manager allows things that should not happen because one of the five has closeness with a member from Human Resources. plus a year of probation with hazing.

review_title: Nice location and community; Overly bureaucratic, Pay can't sustain Bay Area cost of living
pros: Nice campus, smart people, learning culture, decent benefits, excellent vacation / holiday schedule.  Great opportunities for speakers, performances, art / culture, round-tables - if you take the time to seek them out.  Fun sports program.  Excellent Health / wellness program (though that seems to be making some changes for the worst)....
cons: With the astronomical cost of living, and especially housing, in the Bay Area, anyone not in the very top levels of management (or Faculty) will struggle just to make ends meet.  Stanford is a big organization and requires a lot of processes and procedures to keep running.  These have become more stifling in recent years, and in many cases, make it harder to do my job, less efficient, and don't allow me to keep the focus on the customers and clients (students, faculty) because I am so busy struggling with internal processes, tasks and checklists.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student!
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: Advantages include all the resources associated with a multi-billion dollar endowment and prestigious name: great funding for you and your research, lots of professional development opportunities, awesome alumni network.
cons: Funding for students varies from department to department. I'm in the life sciences, and even with our generous stipends, it's hard to afford to live in the Bay Area. Overall, though, a great place to work.

review_title: Stanford is wonderful. The best place I have ever been.
pros: Great environment for any one who devoted her/his life to research and knowledge, in general. The place to be if you want to do great research and be immersed in the intense intellectual life. One of the cross-roads of so many lines of thought and scientific directions. Here you are involved in the cutting-edge research, have a chance to interact with best of the best - Stanford own and world-wide.
cons:
Shares all common problems of science and research - lack of funding, projects ending due to lack of support. 
The new buildings are not well-suited for research and teaching, as weird as it sounds. The lab and office space is scarce, for the sake of huge atrium and other LEED features and amenities.

review_title: An inspiring place for a PhD
pros: The opportunity to learn from the leading researchers in their field and to network with the most important figures in their field is simply unparalleled. The environment is super friendly, the ability to speak with and initiate projects with anyone on campus is astonishing and most classmates are similarly driven and ambitious (for some the latter can me a con). Lastly, despite only being a PhD student, what I love about Stanford is that I feel appreciated by the university.
cons: Administration is often less organized than one would expect and systems being used by the university, such as the main portal through which students interact with university requirements (Axess), is archaic.

review_title: Still a great place to work, but it's becoming more .com than .edu over the past couple years.
pros: Working with some of the brightest people can exceptionally rewarding, provided effort is made to seek partnerships. Life/work balance is well maintained and the overall environment is generally easy-going. Highlights include access to great recreational facilities and on-campus eating establishments, up to two-to-one matching contributions after five years for retirement plans, ability to work from home, free Caltrain annual pass and free money for not driving.
cons: My health insurance premiums went up 233% in one year, although the overall cost is still less than industry average. Retirement plan is confusing and little guidance is provided by the university; it was changed in 2010. Overall pay is still somewhat less than comparable salary in the region.

job_title: Health Educator in San Jose, CA
pros: If you are part of a nice team, you get treated like a community and feel appreciated for your contributions to the project. The benefits which get better with time are having your 401K matched by percent that increases each year you work for Stanford. You also get a solid amount of time off along with Kaiser being the medical option that is free for the individual employee if they wish. You have to be 75% time though to get the benefits like this.
cons: Since this is "soft money", your salary can be changed or funding may not be able to keep you. If you don't work with a PI that has other projects going, you can be let go - - and it is much harder to find another position.

review_title: Excellent place to work, very friendly and professional, beautiful campus
pros: The campus is beautiful and everyone is friendly. No matter what you are doing you will have access to the full resources and benefits of Stanford University (classes, gym, etc). It's a great community you can really make the most of.
cons: Most of the administrative jobs are pretty boring, though a lot are relaxed about letting you do your own projects in addition to your work. It really depends on your role and your management.

review_title: Stanford University has its ups and downs
pros: Simply put, the benefits.  The benefits offered by Stanford University to every employee are competitive with some of the best companies in the world.  The retirement plan offers double matching of the first 5% contributed.  There are multiple health care packages to choose from, offering a spectrum of options.  Educational benefits are also offered, and any class on campus may be audited.  Public transportation passes are offered for free to employees.  Good academic atmosphere.
cons: Pay is not very competitive with other companies.  Like any huge institution, bureaucracy can be extremely annoying.  Driving on campus is discouraged as much as possible, so parking can be a challenge.

job_title: Special Events Patrol Officer (Former) in Stanford, CA
pros: The police department at Stanford is a rich, fulfilling job that connects you to fellow Special Events Patrol officers of all kinds of walks of life.  You set your own hours online (only requirement is to work 20 hours in a full YEAR and be available for football season).  You learn an incredible breadth of skills on the job, from learning how to patrol foothills in a Ranger, to parking enforcement, to traffic control during events with thousands of people. A truly rewarding job that you work on your own time.
cons: As all Special Events Patrol personnel can select their own hours, availability/opportunity to actually work can become restricted without warning. Since roughly 120 SEPs are kept hired at one time, equal division of work can become tedious and difficult since everybody's availability preferences are accomodated.

review_title: Great benefits, good work/life balance, and a chance to work with people who are the best in the world at what they do
job_title: Software Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great vacation benefits
Time off in days: PTO (3), floating holiday (1), vacation (21), sick (21), plus Federal holidays and a two week closure at Christmas
Good health plans
Competitive salary
Good work/life balance
Work with really great, driven, intelligent people
cons:
No profit sharing/bonus structure
Hard to move up because most organizations are very flat
Working with faculty can be difficult
Facilities are not always top-notch

review_title: Great place to study and work. To live? Maybe, if you can afford.
job_title: PhD Student in Palo Alto, CA
pros: A great place to work and study. People in the university are friendly, laid back, yet still very efficient in doing their jobs. It offers a world-class scientific environment. A lot of great seminars by top researchers in the field are offered each quarter. It is a very safe place, both within the campus and in the surrounding area. The weather is always nice. There are a lot of great cafeterias on campus and nearby.
cons: Things are really expensive here. The cafeterias are nice but not cheap for students. Housing is unacceptably expensive, both on- and off-campus. When both food and housing are expensive, a graduate student with a limited stipend can have a hard time making ends meet. In general, it is a place for rich people. Living as a poor graduate student here is sometimes miserable.

review_title: Great place for someone who has other jobs/projects/hobbies on the side.
pros: Excellent work-life balance, great benefits, TONS of discounted and/or free services (gym, professional development classes, etc.). Laid back work environment, as compared to working for industry/corporation. Gorgeous campus. Lots of opportunity to grow professionally and advance in your career.
cons: Low pay, compared to industry standards. Office environment is less "progressive" and less open to change, compared to industry.

review_title: One of the premier academic institions in the world
pros: World-class research. It is the place for electrical engineering, computer science, and bioengineering. Silicon Valley and all of computers came out of Stanford labs. This place is gorgeous and unparalleled. Campus is vast and has tremendous variety.
cons: Quiet, secluded, isolated. Gender balance in most of the technical departments is insanely male-dominated. Area is ridiculously expensive. Cost of living is through the roof.

pros: The brand is incredibly powerful. Access to amazing research facilities. Surrounded by genius people
cons: The area is so expensive. Stanford does not pay postdocs a living wage. Stanford spends enormous amounts of resources on sports facilities, grounds, big events but neglects taking care of postdocs who do a huge amount of research that makes the brand famous. An incredibly bureaucratic organization that does not truly take care of their employees and exploits postdocs terribly.

review_title: Job didn't meet Stanford's reputation for innovation or excellence
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Beautiful campus with good benefits and lots of training opportunities. Great campus to walk and bike in just watch out for all the new construction!
cons: Worked in the Dept. of Environmental Health and Safety and it was a joke. Team managers showed very little professional respect to each other and would stab each other in the backs on a regular basis. Managers were resistant to new ideas and department teams stuck to their own little silos. To survive, staff members basically kept their mouths shut and heads down in fear of being targeted. Very bureaucratic and controlling culture with archaic office procedures that showcased how little management trusted or respected its employees. An example was the sign-in board that was constantly monitored by HR to track comings and goings of staff. Really? Found it to be a generally mean and unfriendly environment. Lots of sad people in this department just waiting to retire or survive until they can use the college benefit for their kids.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Beautiful location, smart people, near San Francisco, good pay, beautiful campus, access to Stanford Hospital, lots of positions and opportunities for lateral moves, great networking throughout Silicon Valley.
cons: Very high cost of living, smart people means lots of competition, people you work with can have difficult personalities, major highways are often very congested making the commutes unpleasant if you can't live near Stanford.

pros: I guess Stanford pays relatively higher than lots of research universities. But whether you'll have a good experience or not really depends on your advisor. And -- for me this is important -- Stanford is a really pretty place to work.
cons: Nothing particularly bad. Again things can be really bad if you have a bad advisor or a bad project, or just get unlucky during a specific phase of your project. You get paid on part-time basis (20 hr / wk) but it's really a full time work. (Probably true for any research assistant in any school anyway)

pros: It's a lovely campus, like working in a park, and the faculty are great to work with. The benefits are very good. Negotiate the best salary you can, as annual increases are low. The way to make a good salary at Stanford is to job jump, or market the Stanford name on your resume.
cons: Once hired, bad managers don't get fired. I've had two managers, one with real anger management issues and the other some employees believe has some form of Asperger's. HR is well aware of these problems via info from departing employees, but does nothing. It's not an uncommon problem at Stanford. If you  have a good manager, Stanford is a great place to work. If you don't, you just need to leave because the situation won't change.

pros: amazing students, spectacular co-workers, beautiful campus, great athletic facilities, never ending learning or speakers
cons:
The first 10 years i was there were awesome. Then we got a new dean and he totally tanked the morale pitting people against each other.  Utopia became hell.  Unfortunately, as in many higher ed institutions, staff are not valued or respected. I don't get it.

It is also hard to 'move up".. There just aren't many opportunities.

BTW, my comments about "management" are for the business school dean not the university president. The university is very fragmented.

job_title: Development Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
-the benefits are competitive
-the job training is thorough
-they pay for commuting via Caltrain
-the stipends for continued education are generous
cons:
-there is no childcare on site (it is over-subscribed and the wait can be years)
-management quality varies and the older people generally have been there over 30 years and refuse to update systems or methodologies
-work/life balance is talked about but never seriously contemplated
-there is a lot of gender bias against women with children, especially single women with children - you are less likely to be promoted even if you put in the same hours as others

pros: Working with world-class faculty and research programs. Access to best and most creative minds in the U.S. (world!).
cons: Dreadful staff management! Managers are selected without consideration of their ability or personality for leadership. If you sit in a chair for decades, you'll get a crown on your head. Bad managers are not fired, just sent to management classes that have no effect. Result is dept staff become demoralized and good staff leave as there is no hope for advancement or even civil treatment.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros:
Students in my research area are generally collaborative and friendly. Professors are also friendly, but tend to be very busy. The type of work I do allows flexibility in working from home and choosing my own work hours, except for a few meetings/talks that I need to attend on campus during the day. 

The campus is beautiful and well-maintained, and there are many nice places to take a walk while thinking about research or talking to colleagues.  

Great alternative commute benefits for graduate students who live off campus.
cons:
PhD research can be very stressful and lack in work-life balance. 

The cost of housing is very high. On campus housing is expensive, and housing in Palo Alto is extremely expensive, even with roommates. 

It seems that buildings are often being demolished and constructed. If construction is next to your work space, it can be distracting.

review_title: Great place to work but little on-campus career opportunities for non-tenure track staff
pros: Bright people and interesting research projects, beautiful walkable campus, a lot of dining and recreation opportunities, 24 vacation days per year starting second year including two weeks of Winter break, separate sick leave, competitive salary considering generous benefits, decent public transportation options including free Caltrain and VTA passes.
cons: Despite enormous endowment administration is not willing to invest university money into research infrastructure, waiting for grant funding which has been abysmal in past few years; there are no long term career development opportunities for professional staff on campus other than finding another job elsewhere; few people are interested in team work; parking may be a hassle.

review_title: Master's and PhD student in Mechanical Engineering
pros: Stanford is the place to come if you want to push yourself to the next level. You get to work with world class people on cutting edge projects. Creativity, science, technology, and entrepreneurship are at the forefront in the Mechanical Engineering department.
cons: It can be intimidating to be at Stanford at first. There is not a lot of guidance in finding what is right for you. But there are so many different opportunities. As with any big university, there is also a lot of bureaucracy.

review_title: Strong benefits, salaries good but not great - Works well for people on second careers
job_title: Associate Director in East Palo Alto, CA
pros: tuition benefit after 5 years is unique in the portfolio of benefits; there is a great deal of support for continued educational development and health and fitness; The intellectual interchange possible on the job and during non-work time keeps one's mind sharp.
cons: The university is very hierarchical and political in structure; programs and processes are often based upon what's always been done versus what should be done; change is slow to come in some organizations; many of the administrative staff are not best skilled resources due to preference given to internal candidates for openings whether the candidate is strongest resource or not

review_title: Good for job security, not so good for advancement.
job_title: Senior User Experience Design Lead in Redwood City, CA
pros: Amazing benefits and stability.  You get to come to work with incredibly intelligent coworkers that really do keep you on your toes.  The group I work in is pretty lax on working from home, which is great when you really want to focus and make progress on your current projects.  They provide a massive amount of vacation and sick time as well, so there's never a feeling of being trapped.
cons: People never leave and very, very rarely get removed from positions. While this is sometimes a good thing, it unfortunately leads to legacy culture and lax attitudes that get in the way of forward momentum.

review_title: One of the best places in the world for graduate school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford's world-class reputation is deserved. Graduate students have access to virtually any class on campus and some very motivated faculty, along with one of the best peer groups you could ask for.
cons: It's hard being a grad student in such a high cost of living area as Palo Alto. Stanford doesn't have enough subsidized on-campus housing to guarantee all grad students housing every year. Even though the Stanford grad student stipend is generous compared to many other schools, the money doesn't go very far in PA. Just a few thousand dollars extra would go a long way towards financial security and comfort while students are in graduate school. Also the health insurance through Cardinal Care seems to be a pretty bad deal, and there's no dental (so I didn't go to the dentist for 5 years...)

review_title: Nice place to work, if you can afford it
pros: Working with the world-class people who work and study here is awesome. The work environment is generally excellent, and the campus is beautiful.
cons: The salaries that the University offers don't keep up with the insanely high cost of living here. Fifteen years ago, it wasn't bad. Five years ago it was worse, but tolerable. Now, deep into the latest silicon valley boom, the salaries that the University offers have fallen so far behind that it really requires a labor of love, or some independent wealth, to keep working here.

review_title: Great quality of life, supportive and enthusiastic management, but paternalistic administration.
pros: Great quality of life, terrific opportunities to engage with the best and the brightest. There's a strong sense of community here. Plus, it's pretty recession-proof. There are no shareholders to please. Working in education makes me feel good about my job. The university pays for commuter options, while other benefits are generous. I can work from home, too. My immediate manager is awesome.
cons: The university administration is somewhat paternalistic and guarded, seemingly too mindful of their image. Leaders in information technology can be too insular, and there's little outreach, education and communication between IT Services and campus community. The university's commitment to IT security seems spotty.

review_title: Not All It's Cracked Up To Be
pros:
- Lots of food options on campus
- Inspiring students to work with
-Sports culture
cons:
- Benefits are not as good as other institutions in the area
-Overwork exempt employees but during non-peak times, treat them like hourly employees keeping them to 9hr workdays 
- Lie that they are for sustainability, but then have managers who make you commute during peak times and departments that write rules to specifically make it so you cannot work from home
- Pay varies drastically by department, my department range is way different than the ones posted online

job_title: Academic Technology Specialist in Stanford, CA
pros: The benefits of being at a large institution are definitely many. There are opportunities if you really look, to interact with wonderful people, research, projects in almost any field. At the same time, the work you get to do is heavily limited by legacy systems that are slow moving and the constant scrounge for funding.
cons: Academia moves extremely slowly unfortunately. Depending on which department you are in, are more importantly, the immediate higher management you work with will to a large extent determine the quality of the work you get to do. Which shouldn't be a problem, but it is, because for the most part, they are so over-burdened that they do not have the will, time or energy to invest in their staff. Resulting in high turnover rates and extremely low staff retention and satisfaction levels.

pros: Lots of support, great co-workers, and super fun! After all, you're basically getting paid to go to camp! Definitely happy with my decision to spend a summer with SPCS.
cons:
Some of the paperwork gets tedious, but that's to be expected when you're dealing with minors.

Not all the support-level staff is helpful. For example, a nurse once asked me what a student's temperature was after I told her the student had twisted his ankle.

And, of course, unless you're going into education, the experience probably isn't applicable to a lot of job fields.

pros: Benefits, Access to athletic facilities
cons: Cost of parking as an employee-- nearly $1,000 per year !  Sr departmental leadership has and nurtures her own favorites.  They will also never - reclassify your job title - if you start at a basic level and take on many more duties and complex tasks -- they keep your salary at the basic level !!  They care of proferroriate and senior leadership - and their few favorites who have been allowed to move outside the area and work and contribute remotely -- full time ?? Yeah right - and the rest are stuck picking up the slack on top of already overloaded work queue!! No room for growth .

pros:
Good work life balance - most people's doors are closed by 5p
Opportunities to participate in low cost employee health programs
Nice campus
Accessible by public transportation - and they pay for it
cons:
Extremely poor communication (in my particular business unit)
Poor managers
Most people who work here are lifetime non-profit people with no experience in the corporate world
Insanely hierarchical, worse than any corporation I've worked for

I realize this is an academic environment and it favors professors. That being said, if the university were run as a for-profit corporation, it would be out of business in a couple of years. In development, they set totally unrealistic goals - and there are zero consequences for not reaching them.

job_title: PhD Student (With Fellowship) in Stanford, CA
pros: Free schedule.  Good stipend and lots of ways to make some more cash on the side.  Amazing resources for graduate student research and quality people to learn from.  Overall probably the best place to be a graduate student in the world, even considering the high cost of living.
cons: 5 years is a longer time than you think.  In most cases have to leave California once you graduate.  Isolating, making it somewhat difficult to develop a network if you want to leave the academy.   Would be better if outside options were treated as just as good as staying within the university.

review_title: Depends on what you are looking for
job_title: Human Resources Administrator in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford has so much to offer someone. Great continuous education options, good benefits, tuition reimbursement for children, employee recognition, free caltrain passes... the list goes on. Pretty much everyone is nice and helpful.
cons: Depending on the field you are working in, there may be little opportunity to be promoted and because it is an educational institution, the pay isn't "at market". Stanford relies on their heavy benefits package to round out the compensation. Since Stanford is like a big business, there is a lot of red tape to go through when getting things done. These are cons for me, but might not be for others. Can't really say anything bad - it all just depends on what you want out of an employer, a job, your career.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Passionate, vibrant community
- Many fun and engaging opportunities on campus
- Beautiful work surroundings
- Flexible schedule in comparison to private sector
- Lots of vacation/pto time
- Overall high quality of co-workers
cons: - There is high turnover in my department as the staff salaries are not competitive enough to keep highly qualified people around. Also, there seems to be quite a few high level management and many lower level administrators, but not enough mid-level positions available. This makes it much more challenging to promote from within and many coworkers leave to other departments for professional growth.

job_title: Applications Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: very good and friendly colleagues to work with. Lots of americans on the department that I worked for and teammates help other team members a lot. At times, tasks are very challenging, and it will be good experience to learn rapid multitasking and improve productivity. monthly get togethers with the team, free drinks and lots of snacks during the afternoon time that is shared by other team members. overall, a very different experience to work here.
cons: Framework developed is used internally, and learning the framework takes time. lots of dynamic setup of the code, understanding all the pieces will be difficult for new developers, so networking with colleagues is really important here. Lots of multitasking on a single day, and compensation is low for the new developers with less experience. salary increase is low for developers.

review_title: Amazing place to work and learn
job_title: Basic Life Science Research Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Lots of support, great status, good benefits, access to amazing resources. One of the most beautiful campuses on earth, great food available, and many places to exercise in an absolutely phenomenal climate.
cons: One of the most expensive places to live in the country / world. Bosses and mentors are self-selected to be workaholics, anti-social savants, and poorly-trained managers. There is lots of HR support if problems arise, but your experience will be heavily influence by the quality, ethics, and choices of your boss/mentor/PI.

review_title: Excellent colleagues and atmosphere overcomes sometimes bureaucracy
pros: commitment to quality (starting with academics but pervading everything), prestige (pays off in finding next job), perks (tuition, library, workout facilities), excellent benefits,  links between university and business, vibrant alum community, parking (expensive and hard to get), generally healthy environment with many lovely buildings, and finally, location, location, location (sunny Palo Alto, easy access to Silicon Valley and SF)
cons: lower pay than corporate, some lack of flexibility (hard to get days off), very difficult (but not impossible) to get part-time work, some silly bureaucracy (this is getting better as more processes are automated), some decisions less than transparent, faculty wrangling,

pros: The brilliant students and faculty
cons: Despite being one of the richest Universities in the world, Stanford refuses to pay its employees living wages. Yes, this includes the people that teach the classes, if they are not tenure-track faculty. And now, even the tenure-track faculty are living paycheck to paycheck, with the administration cutting one-off deals to keep high profile Professors from fleeing this ongoing cost of living crisis. Consider this - if that is how the problem is being 'solved' for the employees they really care about, how likely are things to improve for everyone else?

review_title: Great place, take the time to get to know those you will be working for.
pros:
Location, location, location, seriously, the bay area, the weather, and the silicon valley spirit of entrepreneurship all shape the Stanford environment for the better. The people - by and large the people at Stanford are interesting and fun to be around, if ocassionally somewhat pretentious.

Faculty - many professors as well as being great thinkers are also great communicators and show an active interest in the work direction and well being of those working with and for them.
cons: Faculty - some faculty struggle with interpersonal communication and show little regard for the well being of those around them. Social awkwardness and a tendency to micro-manage can also be big issues.

review_title: Stanford is an outstanding place to work: excellent people, excellent resources, excellent weather.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: As a postdoc, your advisor, of course, matters far more than the particular institution you attend (at least if you plan to become a professor). However, if you have to make a choice between equally attractive labs, and one is at Stanford and the other is on the East Coast, Stanford is a clear winner: the people tend to be friendlier, the weather is far nicer, and in general the institutional resources are similar between Stanford and Harvard/MIT/Princeton.
cons: The cost of living in the Bay Area is high. The minimum postdoc salary for 2014/2015 is ~$45,000, but you're unlikely to find a one-bedroom apartment for less than $2,500 per month. Even a studio apartment typically costs between $1,500 and $2,000.

job_title: Financial Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: If one has a good manager, Stanford is a very pleasant place to work and a person can feel as if they are really making a difference.
cons: If one has an abusive, manager who gossips about their employees and who is mentally abusive, Stanford is a miserable place to work.

review_title: Don't apply unless you know somebody, and if you do get hired w/o knowing somebody, then prepare to be frustrated.
pros: We're in a recession, so working anywhere is better than nothing.
cons: Supervisors don't know what they are doing.

pros:
Stanford is great, many resources such as good funding, seminars, mini-courses, career development. Basically if you want to learn about anything else, there are classes and seminars you can find and go to them.
