Recently they also gave free Cal-train passes to postdocs that live far. So that's very nice.
cons: Housing is a big problem. The school doesn't offer subsidized housing to postdocs, while they offer to students and staff. Living around Palo Alto is VERY expensive. Definitely can not afford it unless you get roommate or live in somebody else's house.

job_title: Stanford Dining Ambassador in Palo Alto, CA
pros: some creative input, some flexibility for new programming, but ultimately constrained by
cons:
everything always has to be approved and re-approved by executives and the marketing department, even if you have the key expertise over an area. It's a little ridiculous. Sometimes you might feel that you are not trusted to do your job thoroughly, and that you would somehow try to soil the brand if given the opportunity. 

Meetings with management are extremely difficult to land, and you might get a cold email from a secretary telling you there is no time for an executive to discuss a certain matter with you.

pros: Working at Stanford looks good on your resume.  The campus is beautiful.  There are a lot of opportunities to enjoy nature.  There are many departments to work in.  People are impressed by Stanford.
cons: Politics are rampant.  Management is a power struggle.  It's all about "Me."  The departments of Stanford are like totally seperate companies.  There needs to be more cooperation.  For cooperation to happen, they need to set politics aside, and think about what's right for Stanford.

review_title: Good Place to work but the campus is not a very stimulating environment
job_title: Financial Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The salary is very competitive particularly for a University. It is a prestige place to work and the weather is good.
cons: Like any high ranking University you are going to come across a fair amount of arrogance. There seems to be a bit of backstabbing and uneeded politicking as well. I also find Stanford University very boring. It is beautiful but it just doesn't have a vibrant social scene like many other campuses.

review_title: No longer a great place to work.
pros: Flexibility - It's very easy to take time off or work from home.  on-campus gym and pools are very nice and employees are encouraged to work out.  great libraries.
cons:
I don't know about the university-level management, but my managers are incompetent.  They don't have visions nor leadership skills.   They won't tell you what they want, then they blame on you for not meeting their expectations.
There is no promotion nor career growth.  If you're satisfied with doing the same thing for the past 10 years, then this is a great place.  Otherwise, time to get out of academia.

pros: My currently workplace is a great environment: Stanford's Department of Management Science and Engineering. I work as a student assistant, and get perks such as the occasional free lunch, the ability to schedule work around my classes, and the ability to work independently.
cons: Sometimes I feel like I'm not trusted nearly as much as I think I deserve. This includes doing above and beyond work such as filing and making copies. Although there are great benefits to this job, there is this one huge downside to it as well.

pros:
Pros are for obvious reasons: the fame, the environment, etc. The job categories provided at Stanford University are huge --- almost anything you can think of, so it really depends on individual cases.
The bottom line: try to avoid  the bottom categories: "Postdoc" or so-called "Research Specialist" which often are treated as dispensable, lowly slaves, rather than "former" staff or employees.
cons: Working under the title of "Postdoc" or "Research Specialist" under a PI is essentially like working under a private slave owner: your whole life depends on one persons' conscience.

job_title: Student Supervisor-Housing Front Desks in Stanford, CA
pros:
A lot of flexibility in hours, worked with my schedule as a student. 
Working at the Front Desk was quiet most of the time, got to do homework and watch Netflix
Paid well for relatively straightforward work
cons:
Some of the Front Desk Supervisors are obviously phoning their jobs in. But a lot of housing staff is made up of former student staff, so I guess it's sort of easy to see the job as a write-off
Kind of confusing chain of command, especially if you stay on into the school year after working for the summer, or vice versa

review_title: Finding time to take advantage of the great benefits is my personal challenge.
job_title: Five Year Staff Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: There are many generations of students, faculty, and staff employees working on a beautiful campus. I like learning from others as we behind the scenes support our students and faculty, mission and longer term goals. It's a complex environment where no two days are the same. Leadership comes in many styles. Across the board, the successful people know how to build and sustain relationships.
cons: Your personal philosophies about working from anywhere, commuting, sharing information, etc. must map well to your team/division. Understanding and appreciating work in a decentralized environment takes time.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Excellent benefits and compensation, employee training and professional growth and development, reknowned name, great co-workers and boss (depends on dept), excellent events, just a world-class environment all round. Great events you can attend, access to Stanford's libraries, free Caltrain pass and VTA bus pass. Free access to gym and sports facilities. Free annual $800 worth of class room training. After 1 year, your 403b (401k equivalent) is matched, increasing for the next 4 years.
cons: Some bosses aren't honest with you about potential improvements you could be making to yourself. Career path and promotions are not as straightforward as I would like

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: Lots of perks-free train and bus transportation from the South Bay (VTA, Caltrain) and SamTrans.  Lots of fun and free events and focus on staying healthy.  Some sporting events tickets (Stanford games).   Some money allotted to use for continuing edcuation classes at Stanford.
cons: Little room for growth in salary or rank for positions like this (Unless you get more education).  They are also understaffed and disorganized and many studies are a bit chaotic.  Plan on juggling more than 10 active studies at once.  Little to no training for the position itself.

pros: They have a very helpful career center for postdocs.   The career center provides seminars as well as one on one meeting with counselors.  The health care benefits are decent.  The campus is very pretty, with many outdoor areas.  Many options for food on campus.
cons: As a postdoc, you are not considered a full employee of the University.  Therefore, a postdoc does not receive the same benefits as a full time Stanford employee.  There is a fee for parking, and the cheaper options means there is a long walk to most buildings.  While the food on campus is good, it is a little expensive.

job_title: Life Science Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Top University, great weather year round, diverse crowd. Good pay and great benefits.
Stanford takes good care of it's employees, lots of free courses and possibilities for advancement.
Located in the middle of high tech hub, provides good contact with companies around.
cons: The place is huge, one can get lost there easily if you don't have clear priority. Lots of management type people with snobby attitude, oh and reach students of course. The salary could be better, espesially taking into account how expensive living in this area is.

pros: Excellent faculty and staff, beautiful campus. Incredible opportunities abound to get jobs, internships, take interesting classes, meet fascinating people. Don't get any benefits because I am actually a student and don't matter at all.
cons: Difficult to get access to some resources. Everyone is smart and that makes a lot of things like doing well in class and motivating yourself to get out of bed in the morning difficult. oh well, it's always sunny and that makes up for a lot.

review_title: Good students; low pay in a position leading to a less-than-glowing future
job_title: Writing Instructor, Program In Writing and Rhetoric in Stanford, CA
pros: The students you will encounter are, on average, smart and well motivated.  One or two are geniuses.  The rest are just hard workers who are a pleasure to be around.
cons: If you're expecting your time as a graduate student and employment as a writing instructor/teaching assistant to lead to work as a tenured humanities professor, you might be in for a rude shock.

review_title: Stanford attracts everybody but lab not.
pros:
Stanford is very good school for education and research. 
Stanford  has the best campus and plenty if resources.
cons: For a research lab, the potential is more decided by the PI, and have not too much connection with the whole school. That is, the style of PI decided your future. After postdoc, for a researcher, there is less chance to be promoted. Many people might just work the whole life as the same title. The salary is less compare to company. It is hard to live in Stanford area. Most important, you can't see the hope of change. If you enjoy and satisfy with current condition, just work the same pace to retire. If want to change, find other way.

pros: I had great autonomy as a writer for the business school.  I had great freedom to write about the companies/topics that were interesting to me and had flexibility to work where and when I needed.  The school also has wonderful amenities and programming (world class speakers, classes, gyms), etc. that you can take advantage of.
cons: The commute and parking situation has gotten worse over the last several years.  Despite purchasing a parking permit, sometimes spots in certain areas of campus are hard to get.  The school is working on improving the situation with various incentives to not drive and to distribute demand for parking throughout the day, but just something to be aware of.

pros: The intellectual and cultural atmosphere cannot be duplicated elsewhere.  There are many opportunities for continuing education and the campus is a beautiful spot.
cons: Many people might feel that salaries are not as high as they might be, but what I find worse is the built in hierarchy which results from academics feeling that they are superior to those who have chosen other career paths.  Particularly among older tenured faculty, a certain attitude of condescension prevails.

job_title: Engineering Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
• Being part of a prestigious organization.
• Being part of an intellectual community.
• Being around college students.  They keep you young at heart.
• Entrepreneurial spirit; Lots of opportunities to try new ideas, projects. . .
• Good benefits.
• Fairly stable work environment. During a recession Stanford becomes an island of relative stability. During boom times, Stanford pay is not competitive. . .
• Great access to sports facilities
cons:
• Highly decentralized environment, hard to know what other offices are doing.  Its like we're all working in different silos.  Cooperation and and collaboration are challenging goals.
• Pay could be better.

review_title: Stanford University - A Great Place To Do Something Meaningful
pros: Great benefits. Beautiful campus. A real community instead of a corporate culture. Work with people from a broad range of backgrounds, ages, cultures, and interests. Working in support of the community instead of the shareholders. Good work-life balance. Good opportunities to work for different departments. Good opportunities for professional development (through classes and conferences).
cons: Salaries are low compared to industry. There are no stock options, but there is generous matching into the retirement plan. You pay for parking, and close parking is expensive and cheap parking is far away.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Mountain View, CA
pros: Stanford offers excellent benefits to postdocs and a great opportunity to advance your career. They also have an entire office dedicated to helping postdocs, which is unique among many academic institutions.
cons: Housing for postdoctoral scholars is a really tough issue. As a postdoc, your pay is not competitive with typical silicon valley salaries. The university does try to pay their postdocs better than other places, but rent could easily be half of your salary depending on your situation.

pros: The main benefits will be the great co-workers and a beautiful campus location.   There are great social interactions with all of the individuals and teams.  The work providing alumni with plenty of opportunities for socializing and educating themselves can feel very rewarding.
cons: For my position there were no paths for advancement.  Take all the training you want, but the career moves would have to be lateral instead of upwards.  The salary growth was minimal despite  changes in the amount of work required and reduced team size.

review_title: Not enough protection for post-doctoral scholars
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Palo Alto, CA
pros: There are ton of resources to help you and a ton of classes and training available.
cons: Competitive nature of the environment at Stanford promotes sociopathic, abusive, and exploitative behavior by some faculty. Definitely not every faculty is like this, only a select few. But I am unlucky enough to be with one of these abusive faculty members. While administration is sympathetic, there is very little real protection for abused postdocs, and very little to no consequences for abusive faculty, so the abusive behavior continues unchecked.

review_title: To LBRE, or not to LBRE
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Colorful scenery, abundant shuttles to and from campus.
cons:
There are many downsides working in this department and this pertains to upper management. LBRE (Land, Buildings & Real Estate) particularly hires people who prefers directing people than rolling up their sleeves to help out when the time is needed.  They are completely siloed and are not team players.  There's no "I" in team.

There was one instance where a customer needed help, which was provided, yet they still complained.  When management got wind of this, there was no fact finding on what really happened nor what next steps should be.  They would rather throw the support personnel under the bus. 

Why would anyone want to work for a place that does this to their employees?  This environment doesn't reward you, but gives the opposite effect.

review_title: Benefits carry the day - or did
job_title: Public Relations Officer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Benefits, benefits, benefits. At least until the 2009 layoffs. The pay wasn't all that great, really,
considering that Silicon Valley was next door. Stanford said it paid salaries at "market rates"
but it was at the lower end of the "market rates," according to outplacement firms who handled
those laid off. True, but not very real.
cons:
If you work for a unit that is not in good favor with Stanford, look out.
You may have a difficult time convincing others that you do work like they
do and they should consider your application for other positions.

pros:
Beautiful campus.
Time to work out in the day 
Nice people
Ability to take free classes right here on campus
Tons of places to eat on campus
Stanford pays you to not drive to work and will pay for your train-lightrail and bus passes
Have I mentioned it's a beautiful campus? 
Ability to telecommute (some departments, mine included)
Lot's of room to grow your career, learn new skills and apply them
cons: For the bay area, you don't earn that much money. In my opinion, that's the only con. Obviously you won't get stock like you could with some other places in the bay area but we are a university, not a tech company.

review_title: Great benefits, intelligent colleagues, independent thinkers
pros: Best part of working at Stanford is the company of intellectuals and access to the best thinkers and researchers in the country/world. The benefits are great-- after the first year, there's more retirement benefits, and very generous health care and transport options. Stanford looks out for the well-being (physical and mental) health of their employees.
cons: My immediate supervisor is not the best manager as he came through the ranks of research-- he's a great thinker/researcher, but doesn't know how to delegate or give useful feedback. The PI for the project is great-- very caring and looks out for his staff/grad students.

pros: Community, good and cheap food, trees, no cars allowed on most of Stanford, gorgeous church, love that it was founded by a believer in Jesus, beautiful grounds and most buildings are too, pay was better than average for my industry, benefits better than average, free buses, free caltrain, post office right there, security is pretty good, park off campus and have a lovely walk to work every day without paying for parking too.
cons: Cutting down too many trees to build more buildings,  built in the lovely oak woodland along El Camino Real and that was sad to see, you have to pay to park anywhere on campus even if you work there, hard to get a job there.

review_title: Nice people, low pressure, little opportunity for advancement for fellows
pros:
The smart people, interesting work, decent benefits.  
You get an opportunity to learn from some great professors.  Not much mentorship in certain areas
cons:
Few fellows make it to professor.  Just a fact of life.  Not much mentorship in certain areas.  It's left to someone taking an interest in you or not.  If your mentor leaves or switches, forget it, you're career as a fellow is stand-still.
Poor parking, poor pay compared to private sector options.

review_title: Great place to learn as an employee, not just as a student
pros:
Stanford attracts smart and thoughtful people as employees as well as students
Beautiful campus with many nice buildings / facilities (not all but many)
Reasonable opportunities to move between departments and positions
Good work-life balance
cons:
Salary below private sector for some positions
Not enough subsidized housing to make living nearby affordable
Work experience can vary from department to department, so it is hard to generalize about the University as a whole

pros: The benefits and pay are excellent and you get the chance to work along side of some of the most brilliant people in the world. The culture and values are everything you would expect from Stanford.
cons: Some departments are poorly run (borderline dysfunctional). Ask around before joining a department if you can. People who have worked there for any length of time will be able to tell you which ones to avoid

review_title: Good research, average benefits, low salaries
pros:
World-class university (good research, prestigious name...)
Beautiful campus with good amenities (gyms, swimming pools, parks, restaurants...)
Easy bike commute
Excellent working environment
Wonderful colleagues
cons:
Lower-than average salaries (a postdoctoral researcher is paid less than a bus driver, only faculty positions and well-protected-by-union technicians are having decent remuneration)
Average benefits (same remark, faculties and techs are fine, postdocs have less benefits than the paid students)

review_title: OK salary but really high cost of living
pros: Stanford looks nice on the CV, it probably helped me land an assistant professor job in a really good research university. People are very smart of course, which helps tremendously to develop a research program for the future.
cons:
The number one problem is the inadequate salary regarding cost of living in the heart of the bay area. 
A close second is the lack of recognition of post-docs: the salary is only a part of it. Post-docs are considered students, meaning they don't get staff benefits. But they don't get student benefits either. Rule of thumb is, if there is a perk out there for some category of the Stanford community, post-docs won't get it.

review_title: Hard to find a more stimulating work environment
pros: Diverse group of extraordinary colleagues and students.  So much knowledge and information right at your fingertips.  Creative energy everywhere, especially thanks to all the efforts to build cross-functional and interdisciplinary research and teaching connections throughout the University.  I do truly feel proud to be a faculty member at Stanford.
cons: Like all organizations, it can be bureaucratic and slow, which is very much at odds with surrounding Silicon Valley.

review_title: Great pay, great experience, good community.
job_title: Residential Computing Consultant in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford Residential Computing understands well that its RCCs are also students, and that our schoolwork should come first and foremost.  At the same time, it is great to be part of a professional community, even while on a university campus.
cons: Being an RCC is not a career, so there is no place to move up to... we just keep our same job (if they like us) and do the same thing from year to year.  After two years of doing it, I have become good at my job, but there is not much new or exciting to keep me enthralled.

review_title: Great environment to work (for non-academic staff positions) but not for career growth.
job_title: Administrative Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits, including tuition reimbursement for yourself (undergraduate and graduate degree) and your dependents (up to four years to complete undergraduate degree).  Free use of athletic facilities (gym, swimming pool, squash, tennis, etc.) health benefits, and matching 401K program. Good work/life balance, so if you have children, it is a flexible place to work.
cons: Low salary relative to industry standard.  Annual increase is very minimal, so you have to negotiate best salary in the beginning or move to other departments or schools (within the University) to get significant increase in salary.

pros: There is a lot of freedom to explore research interests, learn new skills, and attend a wide array of seminars and workshops from almost any academic topic imaginable. Great health insurance too!
cons: Prices are very high in the area, making it hard to find housing, affordable restaurants, etc. I imagine it’s particularly hard for families since a lot of the housing available seems to be aimed at single people (e.g. one room in a 4-5 bedroom house).

review_title: De-centralized. Your exerience will vary widely. Nice place and people.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros:
For the most part, people are nice, well educated, and well meaning. 
Community
Benefits
Good work life balance for staff.
cons:
Difficult to find promotion or salary increase. 
They pay lip service to professional development when there are no career paths to follow. 
Many dead end jobs for staff. Stagnation.
Difficult to move around to new job if you want more responsibility/competitive.

job_title: Systems Administrator II in Stanford, CA
pros: Stability, great people and work environment.  Interesting projects and budget to work with.  Management is always improving which makes Stanford great working environment .
cons: there is no free parking and you do have to pay for the permit.  Traffic is horrific.  It organization is extremely segmented, so if part of your project needs a firewall rule or some other networking need that is covered by some sub department - you better know it in advance and plan for it or add-hack changes will not work and project will fall behind.

review_title: Stanford really welcomes students as workers
pros:
-Great staff
-Access to the entire campus and its resources
-Access to knowledgeable and renowned people in their fields
-Support and security
cons:
-Hard to get a promotion
-Staff gets moved around a lot
-Working with students can be difficult
-Can't keep up with changing technological atmosphere

pros: Educational experience at Stanford is rich. Lots of opportunities for diverse cross-disciplinary interactions. Try to get as much Technology Industry relevant instruction or project experience to take full advantage of the Stanford brand in your next job.
cons: Pay while a Research Associate is hard to live on in the uber-expensive Bay Area. Research staff in academic labs have little room for advancement in the Academic track except for those lucky to get faculty appointments.

review_title: wonderful institution full of great people!
pros: the bay area is awesome! campus is very beautiful. you have access to the best facilities in the world and you have access to some of the smartest people in the world, if you take advantage of it.
cons: as a grad student, you don't really get to enjoy the campus much other than the short walks from my lab in the basement to my collaborator's lab. it doesn't have the easy access to many good cheap food places like berkeley since university ave is a little removed from campus and filled with higher end eateries.

pros: Being on campus and having access to all that goes on there in the class room, at the various schools and within the community.  Being surrounded by people who whole-heartedly believe that what they are doing is important..
cons: Arrogance of some senior staff and faculty.  Lack of support and mentoring for support staff.  The assumption that just having a Stanford job is enough to compensate for a smaller salary.  The amazing tolerance for inefficient people as well as systems and processes.  It can take 14 working days to get an approved PO faxed to the vendor.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The academic standards are undeniable, and the environment is colegial but competitive. Athletic opportunities, both active and spectator are great. Unbelievable facilities. Stanford might be the only university that actually does EVERYTHING really well.
cons: The campus wide and deparental politics are less than ideal. As a researcher, the fact that PI status is only granted to tenure track faculty, and not to research staff, is less than ideal. There is also a serious aversion to faculty hires from within.

review_title: Stanford is a great intellectual hub
pros:
Great intellectual community that collaborate well
Beautiful place to work
Many opportunities to learn soft skills as well as lab skills
Wide variety of core research facilities means there is very little you cannot do on campus
cons:
Very expensive to stay near to campus, and salaries don't compensate accordingly. Also, there is no housing available on campus (grad students and faculty get housing, but not us!).
You could struggle with work/life balance in the academic environment at Stanford.
No teaching opportunities for postdocs.

pros:
Extensive support for professional development through postdoctoral affairs office and many other offices on campus. I haven't heard of any other universities that come close to this kind of support for professional development for postdocs. 

You'll be working with  driven, inspiring, and interesting colleagues.

Perks: Free Caltrain pass. Very low-cost health insurance option available. Beautiful campus.
cons:
The pay is low compared to the cost of living. Hence the Caltrain pass, because it is difficult to afford housing near Stanford.

No matching retirement contributions.

review_title: Great place to be if you enjoy hiking
pros: Stanford is full of friendly people who want to be successful. Many people are more entrepreneurial than in other universities. Of course, there's the weather and the proximity to many hiking trails and tourist attractions in the bay. The Stanford name is also useful after graduating.
cons: Not many people go to Stanford for its proximity to three major cities: San Francisco, San Jose, and Oakland. Unfortunately I did and found not many like-minded people. In terms of career opportunities, do not depend on the CDC. Though they provide many programs to help find yourself, they were not very helpful in securing a job.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Tons of resources available to students, both for research and personal development.  This is *the* place to be to study at any education level.  This is the opportunity to study under the best in their field, no matter what field they're in.  There is plenty to challenge anyone.
cons: Graduate school anywhere can be stressful, but this is more dependent upon the research group you work with.  Salary for graduate students is of course low, but everyone knows that going in.  I never thought so many people could live in such a wonderful place and spend all their time in labs not enjoying the outdoors.

pros: Stanford brings together entrepreneurial, driven kids in a relaxed, west coast atmosphere - the result is a supremely creative environment where you can explore and test different ideas.  Stanford also has a great deal of access to resources.  Not to mention the beautiful campus.
cons:
Some of the more "unique" classes can be staffed with some inexperienced professors that struggle to balance their experiences with real learning.   While the content is interesting, the value can be limited.

Same is true with research, make sure you do your due diligence prior to agreeing to any research position.

job_title: Marketing Intern in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I was an athlete her so when I stopped playing my sport I wanted to stay involved so I became an intern in the marketing department. I loved every minute of it. Everyone is super nice and motivated and working towards a common goal.
cons: The only downside I could see was that there were no hiring opportunities for me when I graduated. I would have loved to continue working there but the only positions they had were for student interns.

review_title: Stanford is a great place to do research, and there is a lot of exciting work happening here.
pros:
- Surrounded by very smart people
- Lots of exciting research happening everywhere
- Diversity in the student body (undergrad and grad) provides many opportunities for collaboration
- Strong support for entrepreneurship
- Easy access to Silicon Valley investors and companies
- Beautiful campus and weather
cons:
- Very expensive to live in the area
- Parking difficult to find if you commute to campus
- Driving within campus is a mess and very slow
- Graduate student pay is low relative to living costs in the area

review_title: Absolutely A Perfect Place to Work
pros: It's very welcoming, the people who work there are intelligent from executives to support staff. They are collaborative, care a lot about work-life balance, and have amazing benefits. Not to mention the campus is a treat to be on every day.
cons: Technology - surprisingly for being in the Silicon Valley they are behind on technology at least on the development side on their fundraising side. That being said they realize it's a weakness and are currently focusing on it.

pros: Smart colleagues, fabulous campus, great benefits (including excellent sports facilities, subsidized exercise classes)  and many continuous learning opportunities. Great community spirit.
cons: HR policies allow people to stay in jobs despite poor performance, or simply be passed on to another department.   Pay is low compared to other Silicon Valley employers, but the college tuition benefit for your kids after you've worked  at Stanford for 5 years means many parents stay in jobs they don't enjoy,  and block opportunities for younger workers.

review_title: Excellent place to start and run a lab
pros: The students and postdocs are excellent, the colleagues are very smart and the campus is gorgeous.
cons: Expensive place to live.  Excessive number of deans and deanlets makes research more expensive than it should be. Few or no endowed professorships.  Excessive bureaucracy and really incompetent admins.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: The university celebrates diversity and its its postdoctoral salary is certainly better than some of the other universities are offering. Beautiful weather also helps!
cons: It is very hard to find a faculty position within the university, postdoctoral is a lot less benefits in comparison to both students and employees on the campus!

pros: The benefits are generally great. Some of the staff are amazing. The pay is good (although for the area, it can be difficult to afford to live here still.)
cons: Because it is such a large bureaucracy, it is hard to find out what your rights are, especially when related to disability. There appears to be little to no training and/or coordination between offices related to this. I was told different things by different people, and my legal rights violated. Without hiring a lawyer, I had few options. Even the disability specialist suggested I just quit. Most of the campus is highly segregated by race/ethnicity and gender.

review_title: Hard to get in, hard to leave
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
This is the elite of academia
Profit is not the motive 
training and professional adv budgets are good
currently college tuition benefits for children of staff is re-imbursed at 50% of Stanford tuition
cons:
It can get political - various kingdoms
I have been seeking career advancement on a technical (non managerial) track and was assured by the director 4 years ago this was possible.
Well, 4 years ago I am still waiting for an update in my job title (I have increased my value via certifications and accomplishments 10x)

review_title: good facilities, weak and complicated administration
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: There are a lot of facilities available, with new equipment coming online all the time. Co-workers and supervisors are generally world-class, very smart. There really is a lot of interesting stuff going on everywhere. And, though it may not seem so from the inside, you can actually find research that is fairly applied if you want to.
cons: As a grad student, it is clear that the administration is not set up to help you. Faculty and "students" (ie- undergrads) get most of the attention. Grad students are in sort of a nether realm and sometimes have to fight a bit for basic employee rights.

review_title: Amazing opportunities for staying involved with the world and current events.
pros: Great environment for lifelong learning. Gentle beautiful surroundings. Lots of diversity both in people but in the working atmosphere, from laid back to very corporate like. Many job types and opportunities across campus.
cons: Lower pay than corporate, lots of 'politics' in many schools. Seems to lack crossover between departments and schools. Each school is its own 'company' and has its own culture and protocols. (This can be both good and bad, I suppose.)

review_title: Great experience and benefits, low pay for Bay Area
pros: I've worked at other top private universities, and Stanford was the best (and I say this as a Cal alum). It has the nicest campus, most resources, connections to industry, impressive faculty, and supports interdisciplinary collaboration. Benefits for full-time employees were excellent (days off/winter break, health/fitness, transportation, retirement, education/training, etc.).
cons: Pay was standard for higher ed but very low compared to private sector salaries and for the cost of living in the Bay Area. Unpleasant commute either by driving (traffic, paying for parking and limited spots) or by Caltrain/BART/Muni (~2 hrs each way to parts of SF).

pros: You can work with the smartest PIs and peer graduate student and postdocs. The research going on is very interesting.
cons: When you see other fresh masters student in CS earns 2-3 times than you do, I think it is hard for anyone to ignore it. Moreover, the cost of living in the bay area is very hgih.

job_title: Director of Development in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Stanford University's reputation and quality of research; strength of faculty and faculty background and accomplishments -past and future possible awards; collaborative environment and vast breadth of research (NIH funded);
cons: competition among the diverse populations of scientists and consttuencies for limited resources can  cause in-fighting; some areas of fund raising have greater faculty participation; other faculty members are more concerned with their own research; there has not been a culture of philanthropy/interst in seeking outside funding.

pros: My job as a junior scientist (fresh PhD) meant that my life was governed by my immediate group, which was excellent group of people, with opportunity for growth and responsibility.  Needed support outside my group one time, and had no difficulty getting it.  Wish I had availed more of the campus resources while I was there, but I was young...
cons: Cost of housing, commute.  For me, living in 2nd tier cities has provided much better quality of life than major metro areas.

review_title: At the top of academic world
pros: Great faculty and students. Incredible breadth of programs. The University is even more decentralized than other universities. It allows for faculty members across the University autonomy to create their own initiatives. Intellectually stimulating place to work.
cons: Organization is slow to change. Decision making can be glacially slow. Often no established career paths for professional staff at middle of organization. Decentralized nature of the university allows multiple and sometimes conflicting programs to be created, sometimes along side one another.

job_title: Division Administrator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Flexibility, no micro management, great benefits, opportunities to grow, recognized for high education & great work, great co-workers & faculty, allowed to work out during lunch, lots of opportunities for free food.
cons: pay is not enough, negotiations is hard, you can grow within the company but takes a few years along with higher income, can be a lot of work at times, turn over rates are average but affects workload,

review_title: MCD: underpaid, poor management, high turnover
job_title: Development Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The bulk of the employees are great people.
cons: Much of the Medical Center Development (MCD) management makes employees feel as if they should be honored to work at Stanford. There is an air of elitism, especially around the concept that they are fundraising for the good of the people. Even though they are underpaid and worked under unreal expectations, there seems to be disbelief that employees are leaving for other opportunities. The toxic environment of MCD inevitably leads to high turnover.

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Stanford, CA
pros: everyone is very friendly and happy to be working there. an excellent community
cons: they could pay us a bit more...

pros: Stanford offers great benefits for Staff employees. The working environment is great. The salary is however on the lower end.
cons: The salary is pretty low in comparison to a similar job in industry. Since the economic downturn Stanford started to cut down holidays and stopped salary increases. Employees are forced to take their holidays within the year.

review_title: Great campus, smart colleagues, nice benefits package, challenging work.
job_title: Product Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The work is challenging, there are plenty of collaboration opportunities, benefits are great, it's a super nice physical environment, you have smart and diverse colleagues, and plenty of extra activities to engage in outside of work.
cons: Not that many!   Parking and driving on campus is a pain, but there are plenty of other commuting options. It's not a startup, so no stock options or other bonus Silicon Valley perks, but the reduction in a stress level is the tradeoff.

review_title: Pretty great for a regular employee
pros: They have great benefits for families, a strong emphasis on work-life balance, and in staffing roles, very nice people. You can definitely find a stable position there, if that's what you're looking for. Proud to be a part of award winning and groundbreaking research. I have seen some of their research impact my loved ones.
cons: I understand that the research is what makes Stanford go round, but a lot of times I feel like the University is a little too deferential to the authority of the PIs and I don't feel that supported by upper management.

pros:
Stanford provides an environment strongly supportive of academic research, collaboration and early career productivity. Ample chances for travel, and large support in academical travel opportunities.

Additionally, the departmental culture feels inclusive and friendly, much helped by the daily tea, sponsored by the department and organized by the grad students.
cons: The commute between Stanford Campus and San Francisco is slightly on the steep side. Furthermore, with the attraction of the university, it's not easy to get traction to deal with the 2-body problem.

pros: The environment is tuned to make you succeed. Fast, pace, great collaborators, fantastic resources. Collaborative and collegial environment, as much as perhaps possible in such a high-tier University and research institute.
cons: Fast pace and competitive environment. You need to work hard, it is likely that stuff will happen with you or not onboard.

pros: Great benefits, excellent institution to have on your resume, generally favorable culture
cons:
While Stanford University purports to have a work-life balance and foster a safe environment in which you can learn and grow, the Graduate School of Business operates like your average bureaucratic organization. 

The Marketing department in particular has notoriously inept leadership and high turnover. Management promotes alumni under the table and then allow said alumni to operate however they want; bullying and micromanaging run rampant. In fact, Stanford caters so broadly to their alumni that they’ll actually repurpose or recycle bad employees, shuffling them around from one job to the other instead of actually getting rid of them. So you’ve got incompetent people in leadership roles that are groomed to believe they are invincible and act accordingly.

Stanford has a 12-month probation period during which they can get rid of you for any reason—or none at all. This is unusual for an organization even by today's draconian at-will employment standards.

You'll be paid below market rate; however, it's fair to note that there are decent opportunities for advancement in some roles. 

Job seekers beware: Hiring managers at the GSB have a very difficult time defining roles and tasks. It’s not at all unusual to have a position very quickly morph into something completely different than what you were hired to do. And if you push back in any way or ask for help, you pretty much put yourself on the chopping block. A good rule of thumb is that if the job seems more involved than the pay and/or title reflect, it's a safe bet that you're being taken advantage of for the sake of budget constraints.

Overall, Stanford definitely has its perks but it can also be more hassle than it’s worth; it all just depends on whom you report to. If you’re considering a position at the GSB—especially if you’re leaving a comfortable job to do so—think long and hard before taking that plunge.

pros:
Beautiful campus.
Interesting people who are passionate about what they do.
Good work/life balance.
Onsite childcare - which, if you can get past the long waitlist, is great and convenient.
cons:
Salary is miserably low, and not at all in line with other Bay Area employers. And yes, many of those employers are private, but making ends meet on the peninsula with Stanford's salary is beyond challenging.

Pay raises are roughly 3 - 3.5%, which doesn't compete with the skyrocketing cost of living in the Bay Area. Bonuses are nominal - if you can get one.

Health benefits are a choice of bad, worse, and worst. Of the handful of plans that are available, the only one that sees low deductibles and copays is the Blue Shield EPO plan. Which, for a family, will cost you a staggering $1,200+ a month for the employee contribution. It's virtually unattainable for staff of the university. Not to mention the 20% increase in YoY cost for 2018.

Career growth is limited. Many people make lateral moves on campus, or leave the university for big promotions.

You have to pay to park. I understand campus visitors paying to park, but staff and faculty? I know of no other area employers who impose parking fees for their employees.

review_title: Politics are alive and well at Stanford University
pros: Relaxed work environment; not micro-managed in terms of clocking in/out. Typically received at least 1 week off during the month of December each year.
cons: There are too many people with too many different agendas. Some people who perform poorly are protected by those higher up within the organization. As a manager of these people, you simply cannot 'get rid' of them without cutting off your own neck.

pros: Excellent benefits, public transportation is compensated.
cons: Salary is not up to standards for the area we live in. I have been here 6 years now and received only 20 cent raises each year along with a letter basically saying "not everyone gets a bonus so be thankful".  Management is a joke. There is zero help and LOTS to do. You will not receive recognition for the hard work and effort you put into your job every day.

pros: Stanford graduate school have a great reputation for academic placement.  Plus it is hard to beat the Palo Alto location.  If you enjoy the student life, and enjoy  the northern California outdoors, then Stanford is the place for you.
cons: Many professors do not care about advising grad students -- only publishing.  This can vary by department, but is especially true in the sciences and engineering.  Also, the quality of the teaching can be quite spotty.  This can be especially disappointing considering Stanford's giant reputation and astronomical tuition.

review_title: Stanford is HUGE. Your experience will depend on where you land.
pros: As an institution, Stanford provides great perks. Decent benefits, although not all are fully covered and I've been spoiled at other jobs. Many opportunities for professional development, which I love. Vibrant intellectual community on campus. I think there may be more staff than students at Stanford! Free gym access where you can work out near some of the world's best athletes. Strong commitment to reducing car traffic by making bicycling easy, and offering free buses. Yet parking can still be found (you just might have to walk a little). Pretty good food in the cafeterias that is, as far as I know, sourced from local and organic farms when possible. Once you are in your job for awhile, your position is fairly secure. Some departments are flexible about letting people work from home sometimes.
cons: I've heard many people complain that the pay is not competitive. Inequity across departments. Each department seems to be run like its own mini-business, and some businesses are more employee-friendly than others. No union for most staff. Politics can come into play. People sometimes worry more about impressing others, laterally or vertically, than about doing what is best for our constituents. For example, if I want access to support at levels beyond my supervisor, I have at times been be discouraged, delayed, ignored, or straight up denied (for example, if I am seeking legal consult in order to ensure I'm working within legal bounds, or wish to collaborate with other departments). Management within departments can sometimes be disorganized, operating reactively without clear direction. Managers sometimes don't seem to have all the training they need to be secure (I think they have access to the training, but that does not mean they are taking advantage of it). Also, while flex-time is mentioned in places on the Stanford website, is is certainly not offered in my department. Most of us feel underpaid and overworked. Overtime occurs on a regular basis. Burnout rates are high, at least in my department. In terms of community service, while some departments offer some, I know some organizations pay employees to do one-to-two days per year. I think Stanford should do more in its community.

pros: Nice place and nice co-workers.  Lots of added amenities to facility usage (fitness gyms, swimming pool, tracks, access to all libraries, discounts to events on campus, free to audit classes -- it is a biggie since Stanford charges a bunch for John Joe from the street to listen in in a class) and being in the center of  the cutting edge of all studies of the human world.
cons: Salary and benefits (medical, dental, vision, sick leave and vacation leave, etc.) subpar to City and County libraries.  It's however, comparable to other University settings like UC Berkeley

pros: The researchers and their work are world-class.  For a physics department of this caliber, there's great work/life balance.  The postdoc salaries are good relative to the rest of the field (though the field is, of course, horrible relative to the "real world").
cons: I don't have a lot of bad stuff to say.  I loved it there.  Parking on campus can be hard to come by, I suppose?

pros: Awesome internship! Great pay for an internship and you get to meet tons of people in their established careers. Free catered world class food for all three meals if you want it! Management was great and you always felt like you could ask questions.
cons: There were definitely some long hours as well as some days you were required to work on the weekends. Sometimes there was nothing for the interns to do as the program was run very smoothly.

pros: Stanford has good benefits in terms of health care for you and your family. It also has a decent matching retirement plan available.  The salaries are comparable to other large non-profit organizations. The free Caltrain card to work is a good money saver, too, assuming you live near a train station.
cons:
-There is no parking and if you find any it is super expensive.
-Inflexible work environment where innovation and creativity are stifled.
-Employee personal development is non-existent.
-There is little support for a work-life balance. Some managers are responsive to having employees who are parents and others just treat them poorly.
-Middle and upper management are very impersonal and provide little feedback on work performance.
-Much of middle management is shuffled around because of inefficiency but there is no motivation to fire them because they have been there too long.
-Talented staff prefer to work elsewhere and there is a significant loss of good staff every year.
-Much of middle and upper management is burned-out.
-Middle and upper management are oblivious to making the best use of some of its staff. People are routinely hired who can do so much more but managers hoard the resource and don't let them collaborate with other departments.
-Departments rarely work well together. There is a lot of territoriality and reluctance to share any resources.
-The highest officers in the department are very removed and don't realize how inefficiently a lot of things are run.
-Transferring (or attempting to transfer) between departments even after many years of service is looked down on and people get overly jealous and defensive about this. Retaliation in this area is common.
-Managers get little training on how to promote the best from their employees.
-The politics feel like a corporate boardroom.
-Most of the non-management staff are always looking for another job.
-There is a lot of red tape to get anything done.

job_title: Major Gift Officer in Stanford, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, living wage, good benefits, and a chance to learn about fundraising from an institution that raises more money than any other university.
cons: Huge bureaucracy, change is very slow if not impossible, questionable hires by senior managment, easy to get pigeonholed, and a surprising lack of willingness to help employees attain work/life balance.

pros:
I'm a 4th yr grad student.

Your phd experience will depend on who you work with and for. Taking care to figure out a good group to join will be critical to your happiness.

Be care for with your school related paperwork. The departmental admins may change fairly frequently and they don't necessarily know what's the required paperwork. Just be careful.
cons:
The cost of living does not scale with the stipend.

If you live on campus, you have no control over your rent and if your department does not increase your stipend, well, buckle up and brace for the impact

pros: worked with great people, learned among the best coaches in the NCAA along with working at great athletic facilities. Free pass to use the recreation facilities.
cons: Like most overnight summer camp it has very long hours and you only get a couple late evenings off a week. For how many hours are worked the per hr. wage is incredibly low.  Typical drama occasionally among the staff.

review_title: The most enriching, inspiring, and fun experience I've ever had
job_title: Senior Research Consultant in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Being surrounded by brilliant people stretches your limits beyond expectations. I was always able to attend seminars held by some of the most interesting entrepreneurs, Nobel laureates, professors, etc. 
I also loved the work environment. One might worry that Stanford is a very competitive place and the environment is toxic but this cannot be further from the truth. My colleagues were extremely collaborative, friendly, and always willing to go out of there way to make me feel welcome. There was almost no competition and it did seem like everyone was simply focused on their tasks. We also had weekly office parties on Fridays in our department where we were able to unwind after a week of work.
cons: The Bay Area is extremely expensive. My salary was ok for other States and although I was aware of the high rent and I did my research prior to moving to California, the effect was still quite shocking. It was a cold shower every time I called a rental agency to ask about an apartment and was given a number around the 5K a month, yes 5K for a 1-bedroom. Stanford housing services weren't particularly responsive or helpful, but maybe that was just my personal experience. Another drawback is parking on campus. It's very tough to find parking on campus in peak hours and I sometimes ended up going around for almost an hour before finding a spot. Biking isn't always an option either because it does rain and it does get cold during winter. I also found Caltrain (the only public transport option) to be utterly ineffective - almost never punctual and runs at random hours.

review_title: Stanford is an unpleasant place to work.  Especially if you are a graduate student.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: People unfamiliar with Stanford think it is a great place.  Your degree will allow you to get interviews at more than a few companies.
cons: You are treated like a cog in a machine, you are disrespected constantly, your ideas are stolen daily, and the benefits are awful.

review_title: As an undergraduate, a great and worthwhile job
pros:
How one approaches this job greatly affects how much you can get out of it. Personally, I found it to be an incredibly rewarding experience; I enjoyed teaching and felt that both students and faculty appreciated the effort we put into the program.

In a nutshell:
Can be as rewarding as one makes it 
Flexible hours (easy to structure TAship around studies)
Significant restructuring to improve student experience in program
Great pay as an undergrad
cons:
Management was at times stubborn (stuck in their ways)
As a mandatory position for many grad. students, co-TAs can be under-engaged

pros: You definitely feel like you are part of something great when you look at all the research and innovation going on around you. Always so much going on - free lectures and conferences on fascinating topics. Great health benefits. Great employee incentives for staying active and healthy, including deeply discounted fitness classes on campus. Free Caltrain and VTA passes.
cons: Some dysfunction in groups and administration, but that is common everywhere. Parking and getting to buildings in the middle of campus can be difficult and time consuming, but not enough to deter anyone from working there.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros:
1. Really talented and inspiring people everywhere.
2. Lots of new and exciting things going on outside of lab.
3. VPGE provides absolutely amazing opportunities for personal/professional development.
cons:
1. The quality of your life really depends on your PI. I have had experience with both good and bad labs, and I would say your PI makes a HUGE difference.
2. There is no mechanism to hold PIs accountable on how they conduct research or treat students.
3. Most University administrators are very nice and eager to help, but bureaucracy slows everything down, and a lot of time new initiatives ended up going nowhere.

review_title: Great people, great benefits, somewhat lower pay
job_title: Administrative Services Administrator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
The benefits are comprehensive, reasonably-priced and offer a fair number of choices.  My coworkers were almost without exception committed and collegial.  Management varies - from excellent to execrable, but that is the case pretty much everywhere.  Also, depending on the location of the job, the surroundings can be amazing, along with unlimited access to a variety of amenities.

Also, during my 15 years at Stanford, for the most part, I was able to work on a schedule that fit with my requirements, and achieve a very good work-life balance.
cons:
Be aware that over the next year to year-and-a-half (starting in March) most support (i.e. IT, finance, business affairs, etc.) positions will be relocating from campus and the adjacent Stanford Research Park to the new Stanford Redwood City campus, located near the intersection of Hwy 101 and 84 (Marsh Rd)  beginning in March, 2019.  This area is already congested, and I fear that the addition of 2,700 jobs is only going to exacerbate the problem. 

I only have anecdotal information to back up this contention, but I believe pay tends to lag behind the for-profit sector in this area.  However, in my experience this was balanced by my ability to put in a straight 40 hours a week which is, I think - as an exempt employee - a rarity in the valley.

I had manager of varying levels of ability and honesty during my time at Stanford.  If you are working directly for tenured faculty, that can be difficult, due to his or her perception of untouchability  This led to frustrations and some ethical conundrums during the early part of my career at Stanford, as I was sometimes called upon to justify the unjustifiable.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros:
forefront of science research
congenial atmosphere, great people
acceptable pay
great education opportunities
clear advancement paths
clear salary and benefits information
cons: There is a pervasive attitude of 'penniless student'.  Hiring is upside down - more professors and researchers than support staff; support staff is chronically over-worked. I know many staff who are covering multiple people's worth of positions.

review_title: A good place to work, somewhat heavy on the administrative bureaucracy.
pros: Highly intelligent workforce doing interesting things. Fair pay overall, attractive benefits. Pleasant work environment. It employs a vast array of professionals in numerous categories and therefore makes for a good place to move within, laterally or up.
cons: A tendency to memorialize everything in formal policy. I'm not sure it's any worse than any other university, but it sometimes seems to hamper internal innovation and tends to discourage an entrepreneurial attitude amongst the workforce.

review_title: Little TA training but great opportunity for career advancement
pros: Networking opportunities are everywhere, and it's good to have teaching experience on the resume. You'll learn more than you think as well. The students are relatively easy to teach as they all want to get good grades - definitely not a TFA position.
cons: Pay is not great, unless you include tuition coverage. There's also very little training before you begin teaching, so a lot of that you'll have to pick up as you go. Some students will feel entitled to your time.

pros: Good Name on Resume, Great benefits and strong work/life balance opportunities. People are generally nice. Secure job.
cons: Its quite decentralized and working together with other departments can be hard if you don't have political power. Systems are archaic and efficiency is poor. pay is below market and many commute from far away in the east bay.

job_title: IT Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: University's academic environment, generally good people and teams, very nice campus and a variety of opportunities make Stanford a good place to work at.
cons: There are many departments that run very inefficiently, and still use some outdated technologies and processes. These can be easily improved but there seems to be a lack of will to do it.

review_title: Stanford it self can be a nice place to work but when the people in charge who should not be they seem to have a problem
job_title: Procurement/Administrative Associate Inventory Planner in Menlo Park, CA
pros: They keep up to date on benefits, etc.  You can learn a lot about people and the right thing to do in life.
cons: They don't always practice what they preach in always doing the right thing.

pros: Intellectually stimulating environment, with interesting people and flexible work schedules.
cons: Staff salaries are not even remotely competitive for the Bay Area. There is no opportunity for advancement, and effectively no internal raises for staff. If you are hired in at a level, you stay there effectively forever. If you are looking at accepting a Stanford job, try to get the highest possible salary for your job band at the start, as that will be your salary for a very long time.

review_title: A great place for graduate study
pros: Stanford has provided me with opportunities galore, a community of students who are invigorated to learn, professors who are at the top of their fields, and a place to work hard but enjoy my weekends and social activities. Courses are rigorous and fast paced but professors are willing to help and be accommodating, and there are many services and tutoring to get help if needed. I love this place! It's beautiful, and every person I meet is so diverse, truly bringing something special to the campus.
cons: I couldn't find one ;)

pros:
-Great benefits
-Dozens of career paths across an astounding number of interesting areas
cons:
-Slow-moving bureaucracy
-Org is unable to apply  what it teaches students to itself
-The only people who will ever matter are faculty

pros: I have absolutely loved my time here at Stanford. I have spent two years here and have worked for stanford in a variety of ways - as a teaching assistant, as a Community Associate, working in two of the libraries, and most importantly, as a graduate student. I can only say good things about all experiences. The people here are fantastic, the campus is beautiful, and the weather is GREAT!
cons: Parking can be a bit tricky sometimes, but it is also manageable once you get a hang of where the lots are.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student!
pros: There are a lot of perks and so many connections to various industries including tech, biotech, and education. There are a lot of resources on campus to help students with professional development, and there are many extracurricular activities students can take advantage of to enhance their overall experience at Stanford.
cons: Despite how much money is available to the school, some of the lab spaces are pretty tight and the equipment is dated. I wish more of the money can trickle down to improving the infrastructure of the lab space.

pros: World's greatest professors and alumni + professional staff = incredible opportunities. It's an exciting place to work and the experiences you'll have as an employee can't be underestimated.
cons: Huge organizations tend to have lots of bureaucracy... Politics within higher education is notorious and Stanford is no different. You'll find some "old guard" admins who can make your work life hell, but those eddies of dysfunction can be avoided if you're smart.

pros: Get to work with great knowledgeable and extremely talented professors and faculty some of which have been awarded Nobel Peace prizes.  The campus in Palo Alto is state of the art with great scenery.
cons: Massive exodus from University IT as many great talented folks have chosen to depart due to poor management execution and decision making.

pros:
- Flexible Schedule, choose your own hours and day of availability 
- Average pay, ask for $18 when you're offered something
- Overall it's an easy job
cons:
- Nasty middle managers
- You will not be treated very well.. at all
- People will yell, scream, and generally act as if the world is ending if you mess up.

pros: Lots of flexibility and autonomy. Good lab mates and excellent facilities. Also, a picturesque and beautiful campus with lots to enjoy.
cons: Stressful and competitive work culture and lots of pressure to publish. Generally this is no different to any post doc, but ultimately the academic system is flawed, especially in Silicon valley, where companies are willing to pay top dollar for good talent.

review_title: Be aware that earning phd is primarily about learning the craft of research. It is not primarily about school.
pros: Guidance from the top researchers in my area had been invaluable to my debrief as a researcher.
cons: Stanford and the surrounding area have few work-life barriers. The cost of living in this area is also extremely high.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford University has an incredible amount of resources that are available to students (undergraduate and graduate) and the network is vast. If you're looking to make something new happen, Stanford is a good place to do it.
cons: Living somewhere close to Stanford is practically impossible, so expect an offensively long commute. Additionally, the environment feels so "polished", its often difficult to deal with circumstances when everything is not, in fact, well.

review_title: Make sure you know what you're getting into.
pros: The bay area is a great place to work.  At Stanford, you can walk, or ride your bike to work everyday.  The research here is very good.  If you want to do important work, this is one of the few places in the country to do it.
cons: This place is a big pond, and while the people are great, everyone is very individualistic.  It is hard to start and maintain collaborations because people are so focused on their own projects.

review_title: Great work environment and outstanding benefits package
pros: They value work-life balance, and provide amazing benefits including large contribution to 403(b) plan. The medical, dental and vision plans are very reasonably priced and offer great coverage. Salary seems to be a little above market. People seem to enjoy their jobs.
cons: It can be hard to get promoted, especially within the same department. Upward mobility requires an employee to apply for a higher level job in a different department. Parking is expensive and hard to find, although they do offer free train passes to all full time employees.

review_title: Resident Assistant in a Freshmen Dorm
pros:
Absolutely one of the most rewarding experiences in terms of employment. Great ability to exercise your own leadership and inter-personal abilities.  

The staff in our dorm are some of the most dedicated and hard working people I have ever met in my life.
cons: Lack of free housing, and very low pay compared to other jobs on campus in terms of amount of work and hours for a certain salary.

review_title: Stanford is a great place to work.
pros: Great people and wonderful location.  The university takes care of the employees.  Free gym membership, walking trails and many other perks.  The work is interesting and many opportunities to meet new people.  Can take classes to stay on top of your game.
cons: Communication could be better at times.  At least within my area.  A huge downfall is driving on campus.  The plus is the train is free for employees.  Free shuttles all over campus.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: Employed for 5 years and loved working with doctors and patients.   Learned a great deal and was able to contribute to leading edge studies.
cons: Lots of growing company pains and higher level managers that don't work together.   I left because the is no career development program for CRCs.  Managers do not value more experience employees, so forced to leave.

review_title: Postdoc benefits overall good, but heath care...
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Matching 401k and other resources make Stanford very competitive in it's total compensation for postdoctoral scholars
cons: The health care insurance provided by Stanford Health Care Alliance is convoluted, complicated, and expensive. Postdocs fall through the cracks in many coverage aspects, which is not typically seen in highly regarded universities.

job_title: Life Science Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great atmosphere to work and gives you competitive benefits, enough to raise the tide at other nearby universities.  Has multiple programs to help offset the costs of child care, health care, and rides for people who aren't high earners.
cons: Stanford is unfortunately in Palo Alto, so it is expensive as heck to live nearby, and even far away requires a high rent and a high commute time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Nice place to live and work. People are friendly. You can always see professors and students having coffees under sunshine. Infrastructure is good. There is a big shopping center and a hospital nearby.
cons: Too many constructions on campus. Noise and dust is annoying at those construction sites. Sometimes they block the road and you have to detour, which is annoying as well.

review_title: Terrific place to work with great work/life balance
job_title: Associate Director of Development in Stanford, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, wonderful culture of collaboration, feel valued as an employee, the campus is gorgeous, a lot of flexibility to work remotely.
cons: Salaries are not very competitive compared to anything in the private sector in the Bay Area, no possibilities for bonuses or equity awards, potential for upward mobility is somewhat limited.

pros: I work in one of the schools ( EARTH SCIENCES) which is like working for a small company. Lots of autonomy, flexibility in decision making, a great culture and environment. The people are nice a fun to work with great leadership in our new dean and his staff.
cons: PARKING! As others have said, you pay ($1,100/year) for a permit to look for parking. Also, some of the systems are pretty antiquated for the Silicon Valley.

review_title: Good life/work balance, benefits..but awful management.
pros: Excellent benefits. Good pay compared to other higher education institutions. Flexible hours. Can take time off when needed. Nice weather.
cons: Open contempt between managers, with lots of partisanship. Top managers insist on micromanaging all technical decisions, despite their lack of relevant technical knowledge. Too much focus on taking credit for ideas.  Unrealistic or unclear goals  or often no goals at all.

pros: Great place for collaboration. Number of amazing postdocs who can run their own labs but still stuck here due to limited number of academic jobs.
cons: No work life balance. "Work until you produce the beautiful graph and we dont care how mnay hours a week you put in"  seems to be the motto of this place.

pros: Sort of free schedule as a graduate student. Some PI's are better than others. It's great to get payed while getting degrees, however.
cons: I work 50-70 hours per week for a new professor. I see other students doing more like 40-50, I see still others sleeping in lab. If you're committed and love what you do it's fine.

pros: Good benefits, prestige, pleasant surroundings, intelligent colleagues, adequate salary, good work environment
cons: I shouldn't generalize but it felt like a little too often there's a culture of keeping interactions pleasant at the expense of being sincere and direct, which can lead to some passive aggressiveness. That's not very much of a con, though, and it's a culture that could be found almost anywhere -- nor is it the worst. Really, I don't have any cons -- but I had to enter something!

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Stanford, CA
pros:
Stanford provides great benefits (caltrain passes, use of athletic facilities, discounted fitness classes and much more), work-life balance and a beautiful place to work. You get paid to bike to work. Lots of vacation time. Campus closes down for two weeks each winter.
Work atmosphere will vary by department.

My department had a work from home day each week. It provided ample training and professional development opportunities. We had flexible work hours as well.
cons:
Parking on campus can be challenging.
Some departments aren't that enjoyable to work for.
Regular staff are being moved off of campus.

review_title: A lot of freedom to pursue research interests, limited growth potential
job_title: Basic Life Science Senior Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros: Good benefits and nice support for a reasonable work/life balance.  As a research scientist I'm given a lot of flexibility with timelines that are longer than the Quarter by Quarter I've experience in industry.  Very generous vacation and sick leave policy.
cons: Lower compensation than industry and lax attitudes regarding safety.  Poor HR support for interpersonal conflicts.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford has great resources for Postdocs both in the School of Humanities and Sciences and the School of Medicine.  In addition to the multitude of scientific seminars, they have organized several professional development series.  Most recently they added personal wellness workshops as well.
cons: On the downside, there isn't a lot of time to dedicate towards your personal development and training.  What good are these amazing workshops and seminars, if you can't find the time to take them?  Not unlike other institutions, research is intense and expectations are high.

review_title: Stimulating environment and cutting edge research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working with the smartest people in the world. Encouraging interdisciplinary research collaboration. Access to the high tech instruments that may not be available in other universities. Internal scientists often give worldclass lectures on campus. Invited speakers for seminars are usually significant contributors of the field.
cons: Cumbersome reagent ordering system (if it's a non-catalog request). Poor processing of administration / bureaucracy (cumbersome paper work and sometimes missing paychecks...).  Salary for researchers is disproportional to the extremely high living expenses in the bay area.

pros: Work is not difficult or challenging.
cons: A lack of merit-driven promotions; too much, "I got here because my parents are this person or that person OR know this person and that person". Work is not difficult or challenging.

pros: At the heart of Biotech kingdom
cons:
- Scientists are sometimes hard to communicate with (not everyone but some are socially  
   very awkward)
- Some Stanford folks are too full of themselves but there are equally amazing people so try to choose well

review_title: Stay away from the School of Medicine
job_title: Simulation Technology Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Health benefits, name recognition, money for equipment, paid holidays. You will work with brilliant and dedicated physicians. People come from around the world to check out programs at Stanford. Employees working in areas outside the school of medicine seem much happier than those inside it.
cons: Sociopathic managers, poor salary, no advancement, poor work-life balance. Many managers answer to essentially no one. Micromanagement and nasty emails are rampant. Working harder or doing better work does not result in better treatment. Turnover in my department was over 50% during my time there.

pros: The work environment is slow. The schedule is fairly routine of 9 to 5. If you have a role that is worthwhile, this can be the place for you to retire.
cons: The values are well defined, but no one seems to follow it. It is more of a lip service that actually believe in them. Culture is very hierarchical. Accountability does not exist. Promotions are not based on ability and accomplishment. Culture tend to be very secretive with no transparency.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros:
Amazing faculty and peers. 
Easy access to great facilities and flexibility to work. 
Free sitting in on courses
Connections with the Silicon Valley 

All of these sets up a Stanford graduate for a good career.
cons:
The duck syndrome- that your peers always seem less stressed out than you on the surface, but under water they are paddling madly.
The bubble - Stanford is a bubble and protects you from the real world outside. Move out of campus as soon as possible!
High cost of living- real estate is a resource.

pros: Stanford is a wonderful place to work with an incredible amount of benefits and wonderfully intelligent people working all over campus.
cons: Stanford does a terrible job paying its lower-level employees and does not care that many people on campus do not make a living wage.

pros: All the resources in the world! Stellar research. Easy to collaborate with industry. You will be challenged and you will learn how to do high-quality research.
cons: Professors might not be as able to meet depending on how busy they are. You'll have to learn how to be independent.

pros:
Working for a worthwhile mission
Smart, dedicated co-workers
Engaged audience/customer base
Management team and staff who "live" the business
Stanford resources
cons: Difficulty addressing and implementing change

review_title: Great Benefits, Great People - Inconsistent Culture, Non-Competitive Pay
job_title: Software Developer in Redwood City, CA
pros: The people are very friendly, and the culture that most departments promote is wonderful. If you work on campus you get to see the wonderful scenery. Lots of incentives for work life balance and sustainable commuting.
cons: Pay can be not so competitive compared to other places, parking prices are outrageous. The decentralized nature of the campus's organization makes for a very inconsistent experience working at Stanford. Some people love it, some people not as much. Overall, it is a great organization.
