pros: Fantastic benefits, great pristige, and a tremendous amount of opportunities. An environment meant for higher learning and exploration. Not to mention, an absolutely gorgous campus.
cons: There are some shortcomings that you need to be able to deal with. Some of the upper management seem to have a need to excercise to much control over thei employees.

review_title: Great experiences working for a wonderful employer
pros: Great employee benefits, beautiful campus, good work environment. Great opportunities for employee career advancement.  The campus has a lot to offer, great activities, and events. Comfortable place and you work with really enthusiastic and diverse people.
cons: Limited means of going up in certain projects; possibly to expand career with employee benefits (pay for school tuition, additional classes). There is a bit of the elitist attitude, but around only a few people. Overall, a lot of people tend to be more down to earth.

pros: Stable environment and less volatile than the private sector, beautiful campus, great brand recognition.
cons: There's a 2-class system with faculty and staff; people are nice but not mind blowingly impressive,  the culture is such that mediocrity is often tolerated. If you function in a slightly more aggressive way than "we're all a family, let's not rock the boat", you may not be well received.

review_title: Amazing place to do a Masters degree in CS
pros: Your peers are super smart! The professors are very knowledgeable and work really hard to prepare for their classes. One can learn a lot from both the professors and their peers. I would also recommend taking some of the fun courses like dancing to get the most out of your time at Stanford.
cons: You need to be on your toes and be ready for the gruelling schedule of the quarter system, it is definitely an effort to keep up with the pace.

pros: Are classified as a student, which enables student loan deferment and other benefits.  Beautiful campus with open feel despite being in a densely populated area.
cons: Are classified as a student, which limits access to employee benefits and rights.  Success is highly dependent upon the principal investigator and there is no current method for properly vetting any PI qualifications as a mentor.

pros:
- Top schools for Engineering, Science/Humanities, Medicine, Law, and Business, all within short biking distance.
- Many opportunities to engage across disciplines and schools.
- The Bay Area / Silicon Valley is an extremely dynamic place to live.
cons:
- High cost of living (PhD student stipend is comfortable, though).
- Slight shortage of housing for graduate students.

pros: Lots of freedom.  Can change professors and topics, work whenever you want.  Can take classes in other departments.
cons: Don't know how you're doing.  Don't have clear goals or feedback.  Lots of politics in what to study, how to get grants, how to get a job as a professor.

job_title: R&D Engineer II in Stanford, CA
pros: Hours, community, little or no travel, and access to ongoing professional education opportunities at a high level.
cons: No opportunities for leadership or advancement - the job you start with is the job you die with. All leadership roles are filled by faculty. Do not come here if you are not faculty and you are ambitious.

pros: You can say you work at Stanford University. Being surrounded by intellectuals who have a wealth of knowledge. Perks and sweeteners that are a plus like free gym membership and discounts at retailers such as Apple and AT&T.
cons: Stress, an unwritten rule that you must be perfect. Difficult to find affordable housing in the surrounding area. This leads to a long commute and drains your wallet and contributes to less of a work life balance.

review_title: Great mission, beautiful campus, work groups vary widely
pros: Stanford has a great mission in its research and teaching. It's is very friendly to those who use public transit. It's is a beautiful place to work, though many non-academic jobs are being shifted off campus.
cons: Each work group is very different, so employee experiences vary widely. Some depend upon external funding and the success of the group in securing and maintaining such funding.

job_title: Operations Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Friendly staff, faculty and students; flexibility; great benefits; beautiful campus environment
cons: lack of good management/ leadership; exceptions are the norm; lack of growth and organizational effectiveness; not enough staff resources (housing/childcare); expensive area and cost of living growth is minimal

job_title: Neurobiology Research Technician in Stanford, CA
pros: Great university resources, salary based on education, pretty campus, LGBT friendly, modern equipment in work environment, as well as being a reputable and prestigious university.
cons: There are not many downsides to working at such a credible institution. It may be a bit hard to get some research noticed within the local community, but chances are it won't be a problem to publish an article in Cell or Nature. The local community has a high cost of living expense, but the university tries to compensate for it.

review_title: Work-Life Balance depends on which department manager you have
pros: Love the benefits of having vacation, PTO, sick and winter shutdown.  Great co-workers, really smart and want to do the right thing.
cons: Pay $700+ per year for a parking permit - a license to hunt, not to park.

review_title: Great environment and campus. Need more opportunities for growth.
pros: Environment is really great with nice weather and spacious campus. People are nice and intellectual. Good to have them around to exchange ideas and have inspirational conversations.
cons: I work in a lab and people come and go. Supposedly there are a lot of faculties and staffs, students and lab members but I don't see them around often. Feel a little too independent and more opportunities to learn new skills will be great.

job_title: Life Sciences Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Very professional and organized, nice orientation provided with breakfast, each website is very detailed and easy to follow, lots of benefit programs to employee including a bewell health program where cash incentives are rewarded for taking steps to a healthier lifestyle (mental and physical). Caltrain Gopass provided.
cons: Parking can be expensive, however they provided many transportation alternatives such as caltrain passes, providing carpool assistance, and bicycle incentives.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Excellent resources, brilliant academic scientists, exciting research.  numerous opportunities for postdocs to grow and explore various career paths (academia or industry).  beautiful campus and flexible hours.
cons: quality of lab/research is very dependent on the professor.  my personal experience:  professor mostly absent and poor unity in group.  resources can be a bit scattered on campus and somewhat decentralized.  parking on campus is pricey and the postdoc salary makes it difficult to make ends meet in the bay area.

job_title: Continuing Studies Instructor in Oakland, CA
pros: The program attracts a good, diverse group of students, and the people who run the online continuing studies program are friendly and professional.
cons: More time spent on administrative work than connecting with students and teaching. Stanford Continuing Studies switched continuing studies instructors to hourly workers, reducing teacher pay and requiring instructors to waste time entering hours.

job_title: Program Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Good benefits
Beautiful campus
Fun staff programs and activities
Stability, it's hard to get fired from Stanford
Pretty good work/life balance
cons:
the Staff/Faculty dynamic is pretty horrible - some faculty members pretty much get away with murder and they are not held accountable for their actions
Low pay
Not many opportunities for growth
Stagnate learning environment, not very challenging
Very siloed - inconsistent titles, job duties and pay across different departments

review_title: Teaching Assistant - made 25k/year working half time
pros:
Paid for my tuition to attend graduate school full-time
The small living stipend provided for basic living expenses and allowed me to live on campus
I learned a lot on the job and had formal training as well.
cons:
The job was stressful at times (what jobs aren't?)
There were a lot of areas I didn't feel adequately knowledgeable about and it didn't seem like there was a good resource to go to.

review_title: A  great part time work experience characterized my time with RD&E.  I had a good time working in Suites dining.
pros: Minimum pay of 15$ an hour and free food.  I also enjoyed socializing and getting to know the people in my dining society that I had the privilege to be a part of.
cons: The challenges included cleaning food that was extremely stuck onto pans and dealing with  a tough, yet rewarding, study and work schedule.  It really humbled me while working for Suites.

review_title: Horrible, worst place I have ever worked. I worked in R&DE IT.
job_title: Senior User Systems Analyst in Stanford, CA
pros: The pay is very good, vacation time, holiday closure for 2 weeks at Christmas time
cons: Unorganized, no structure, lack of professionalism, arrogant associate and Sr. Directors who's egos need to be constantly coddled. Lack of direction, want employee to wear multiple hats with unrealistic expectations, don't see the need to change a system that is not functioning correctly, employees who are resistant to change, leaders who have no business working in IT as they lack experience and knowledge.

job_title: Bio Statistician in Redwood City, CA
cons:
Commuting to campus is, generally, very horrible.  
Space is a huge issue -- my workspace is basically a closet with no room to spread out or get comfortable, and it's only going to get worse as more people are hired and we have no space to which to expand
There are definitely a few big egos, but they are scattered around so I don't have to deal with them often.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: Amazing array of top professors and research projects. If you love doing science and working with like-minded people you are in the right place!
cons: Much of your quality of life is determined by your relationship with your advisor. This is probably as it should be - but be aware of this when choosing who you are going to work with for the next 5+ years.

review_title: Great benefits; do your due diligence on your direct report
pros: Intellectually stimulating, good benefits, generous time off, room for growth
cons: Low pay for Silicon Valley; Stanford has a middle management problem; snob factor; commuting is a pain; living close is impossible.

pros: Great place to do research work, especially from an engineer's perspective. Culture of openness is good, and allows people to share a lot of information. Very beneficial for the thesis work.
cons: Engineering department is a big place. Sometimes, especially at first, it feels impersonal, but when you get to know how things work, it's a great place with a lot of smart people.

review_title: PhD in Materials Science and Engineering
pros: A lot of really smart people, great resources and diversity. You can really excel if you truly love science. The department is well funded. Free doughnut every Monday. Free tea, and sometimes free coffee, for all. People are very friendly and Professors are approachable.
cons: Office environment of PhD students are not really conducive (no windows and sometimes can be stifling), but I guess the condition will be similar, if not worse, in other universities too.

review_title: Stanford is a power-house environment that needs to work on building a culture of social responsibility.
pros: Colleagues are almost all brilliant and driven, which elevates the work product and experience. Funding is strong. Students are great. Infrastructure is amazing. Environment is stunningly beautiful. Climate is perfect all year round. Salaries are competitive.
cons: Colleagues could learn more humility, compassion, and social responsibility.

job_title: Research Project Manager in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Fantastic benefits and employee wellness programs, great alternative commute incentives, annual performance review can lead to regular raises, solid retirement savings policies, access to gym facilities
cons: High pressure to perform and publish, parking at work costs at least $30/month and is limited, and a lot of positions are contracted for only one year at a time

job_title: Assistant Director of Annual Giving in Stanford, CA
pros: You get to work with incredibly bright and talented faculty, staff, and alumni. The benefits are great, with tons of additional perks outside the standard medical/vision/retirement, etc. Stanford really cares about employees health and wellness and work/life balance.
cons: Sometimes management seemed a bit out of the loop on what everyone else was up to and potentially had unrealistic expectations because of this.

pros: The John S. Knight journalism fellowship at Stanford is an extremely thoughtful and well-run program. The directors are supportive while being challenging. The program connects fellows with world-class thought leaders and entrepreneurs.
cons: The fellowship only lasts for eleven months so you need to squeeze every drop of goodness from it that you can in that time period.

review_title: Micromanagement, Payment Delays, and Manipulative Hiring
pros: - Free gym membership at Stanford
cons:
- HR fudges the hiring process, with huge delays,  but doesn't compensate for living expenses and lost pay associated with more than two weeks of a delayed start date.
- Boss micromanaged me on routine data entry, remotely from New Hampshire, making it impossible to complete projects.
- Strict academic hierarchy means your insights and alarm-bells on major cost overruns will be ignored. 
- Hire more than one person in a single role without telling you, so that they can cut positions at will; do not work here as a temp worker for that reason.
- Low pay and no benefits; consistent pay processing issues.
- Poor communication and big egos.

review_title: I was a software developer at a subsidiary of the Stanford Libraries.
job_title: Software Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The retirement benefits are excellent.  Some of the perks are really nice.  If you happen to work on campus, I understand that the professional development is excellent.
cons: Unfortunately, if you don't happen to work on campus, the professional development is nonexistent.  Our management did nothing to invest in our careers or skills.  As a result, the longer anyone worked there, the further behind their skill set slipped.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: I enjoyed my work there.  Flexible and reasonable hours, in general.   I biked to work and received compensation for giving up my parking spot.
cons: Advancement and career track for clinical research coordinators needs work.  Very slow to improve systems and implement effective changes.  Most workers are older (sometimes old school in their methods and mindset) and often unreceptive to change and innovation.  As a younger staff member this could be frustrating.

pros: very receptive to life issues, not too many rules to stifle growth or outside of the box thinking, beautiful work environment, everyone was very friendly and supportive.
cons: certain amount of bureaucracy is to be expected, occasional confusion as to what the exact process for assignment of tasks and the schedule for the completion of those tasks

review_title: It really depends on the manager you have.  My experience here has been very positive.
pros: It is a very entrepreneurial environment in my experience.  If you have a good idea and find the right faculty member to pitch it to while aligning it with organizational goals, you will probably get it approved.
cons: Like most higher education organizations, it is decentralized and being able to build bridges across units and learning to work cross-functionally with peers are very necessary skill-sets.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros:
-Relaxed atmosphere
-Access to world class equipment
-Several staff scientists to keep equipment up and running
-Access to several top professors
-Extremely intelligent community of graduate students
-Contributions are valued
-Excellent recreational facilities
-Huge endowment for construction projects and equipment
cons:
-Consequence of world class equipment is that it can be finicky
-Some faculty can be busy due to numerous traveling requirements

pros: Best benefits of any job I've ever had - free gym access, free Caltrain pass and other commuting benefits, great retirement matching, beautiful campus/work environment, etc
cons: Hired as a part-timer for a full-time position. Since I was an exempt employee (i.e. not eligible for over-time), I worked many more hours than I was paid for. I ended up resigning. Despite my disappointment that the part-time position did work out, I wouldn't discourage others from pursuing a full-time position at the university.

review_title: not a great place to build a career, poor management, extremely low pay
pros: great brand name; looks good on cv; nice campus; if you are looking for a slow pace work environment this is your place
cons: very low pay, no oversight of management, no room for career growth, tiny pay increases, they don't take care of their employees

job_title: Staff Research Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Great labs, very collaborative environment, postdocs are well taken care of, reasonable compensation and benefits, access to resources on campus.
cons: Depending on the lab and mentor, your postdoc experience could be great or terrible! Have to choose wisely as it is a big commitment.

review_title: Great location, nice people, job nebulous
job_title: Technical Writing Consultant in Stanford, CA
pros: It's wonderful to be part of a thriving community composed of students, professors, and professional employees
cons: Very much stuck in the past when it comes to technology and the IT management there doesn't seem to understand much in the way of human relations.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: Great environment with excellent lab facilities, professors, classes, and research programs. Collaborative environment.
cons: PhD salary is comparable to other universities, but the cost of living in the area is very high. While a great education is received and opportunities opened, do not expect to be saving much money or any closer to being able to purchase a home from this job.

pros: They have a lot of educational programs, classes, services etc to help you advance in your career. The benefits are good, especially the health plan.
cons: The commute is really rough coming from San Jose. Also, it varies a lot by department, but in my experience admins have to figure a lot out for themselves very quickly as to how to do things they haven't been trained on.

pros: There is a wealth of great minds and great programs at Stanford. There is also a great career center for post-docs and the do a great job helping you transition into a career. Definitely a good place to work.
cons: Sometimes because it's so big you can get lost in the shuffle. It will be up to you to make things happen for yourself.

review_title: Exciting, Encouraging, Career expanding, Mind Expanding.
pros:
Employees are treated well.
There is lots of opportunity and encouragement to build and grow a career and take on responsibility.
Facilities and resources are second to none.
cons: Everyone else is energized and excited to be working at Stanford University, which translates into intense competition. So many people being so creative results in some overlap and inter-department issues.

pros: Good benefits, students are really nice, good food & lots of resources available. Good place to learn if people are willing to give you the opportunity.
cons: Very political, some people who are above you sure treat you like they are better than you. Lots of back stabbing from some. Not everyone is friendly and willing to help.

pros: Working as a research assistant here will help you to get a higher-up job elsewhere due to the name recognition of the institution.
cons: Research assistantship positions are increasingly scarce due to the poor job market, which leads PhD students to remain at the University continuing to conduct research and competing with current students.

pros: Wonderful campus, weather, friendly people.  Amazing research and collaboration atmosphere.
cons: The modern American tenure-track is institutionally, severely dysfunctional.  Also, interdisciplinary work is still very difficult unless someone is already doing it.

review_title: A very interesting place to work, with great benefits and a lively campus atmosphere.
pros: Great benefits and access to campus facilities, including library, dining, athletics and fitness programs.  Also access to some campus courses and training programs.  Stanford also has a progressive transportation program, providing incentives for alternative commutes, including free passes for Caltrain and local bus networks.
cons: Although it's a beautiful campus, it's a large campus to get around, so be prepared to coordinate shuttle buses, walk, or ride a bike.

review_title: Stanford is THE place to do a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: Anyone who is anyone comes to either be a professor here or to give seminars here so you will never have a shortage of experts to network and discuss your research with. The resources are endless here, not to mention that Stanford has some of the best weather for a university in the entire US.
cons: Everyone is into big data high throughput anything, so true basic research can often be looked down upon as old-fashioned.

review_title: Spend some time at Stanford if you have the chance to do so.
pros: In an academic job at Stanford you work with, or for, the best minds in the world. The potential for personal and professional development is almost limitless. This is straightforward: Stanford is indeed all it's made out to be.
cons: The competition is fierce. Sometimes this can be a little dehumanizing, but my experience is that it's better here than at, say, MIT.

pros: Great opportunity for learning. Many classes are open for staff to take and there is a tremendous amount of seminars to participate in. The benefits are great.
cons: The position would be great is you are looking for a job as a researcher. However, the staff positions may not be as exciting as research.

review_title: Stanford University is a great place for graduate work
pros: Great part of the country.  Cutting edge technology.  Ability to create change where needed (not a lot of red tape to get through)
cons: Advisors are frequently distracted by other obligations (starting companies, etc).  Not a lot of emphasis on career or personal development.

review_title: Good pay for fun work with very smart people
job_title: Free Roving Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros:
Near European quality of health and retirement  benefits

Great choice of health insurances, from Kaiser to Blue Shield.
Retirement managers TIAA/CREF brought me through the 2008/2009 debacle, but if you want to risk more, they also have Fi9delity
cons: I did not find anything beyond petty grievances, you can make up about any emp-loyer.

review_title: Stanford - A great place to work!
pros: Atmosphere, flexible schedules, work life balance, company benefits, excellent culture.
cons: Pay. The pay is lower than the average rate in the area, but I suppose that is to be expected of a Learning Institution. When I was there, there was also a salary freeze for 2-3 years. Once raises went back into place, it was pocket change. Literally.

pros: Stanford is swimming in money, although you don't always notice it in your salary.  The facilities are impeccable and faculty have lots of funding for travel and research.  This gives you lots of opportunities to excel as a graduate student, and prepare yourself for your next job.
cons: It's far from the city, but also far from affordable housing.  Student housing is always over capacity.  Bias against conservative or religious viewpoints is pronounced, even by Bay Area standards.

pros: Obviously, getting to say you worked at Stanford is pretty great. The faculty, students, and staff are some of the brightest minds on the planet and the campus is gorgeous. Having access to these people and this place was wonderful.
cons: Just like any other university, it is political and bureaucratic. People often favor people who have been at Stanford for a while, thus getting some people promoted into positions they cannot handle. And there is a deference to VIPs that is disappointing.

job_title: Event Planner II in Stanford, CA
pros: Meaningful work related to Stanford's education goals. Great Silicon Valley partners and clents. Awesome hours, work from home options, and outstanding benefits. Benefits worth as much as the competitive salaries.
cons: Job categories can be stringent. It's good and bad for lateral and upward mobility. Projects can move slowly. Programming can be challenging as funds are released often over time.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Tons of resources
great career center
great libraries
great colleagues
great networking opportunities to find VCs 
almost every other person is doing a start-up
great resources
great commuting benefits
cons:
overall everybody is highly competitive, and sometimes not in a healthy way
one could be trapped into the perception of Stanford's the best of the best
housing and everything around Stanford is very expensive
since Stanford has the largest campus in the US, sometimes it takes over 30mins to get to a certain building
food options are okay but expensive

pros: Good medical benefits (Stanford Healthcare Alliance), decent retirement plan, a generous amount of PTO time, beautiful campus, many food options and free access to gyms.
cons: Long commute (who can afford to live in Palo Alto??). Parking is tough. Management tends to overwork employees, giving them more and more work the longer you work there. The pay is decent depending on your role, but they could pay higher, especially since we're in Silicon Valley. No flexible hours or telecommuting options.

pros: Great opportunities to excel in field, interact with leading scholars, exchange ideas, and pursue research. Committed faculty. Great weather.
cons: Graduate stipends don't go as far as they used to. Finding affordable housing in the area has become a nightmare. Somewhat isolated from east coast schools.

job_title: Data Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great benefits including vacation and retirement contributions.
In general, Stanford is very conservative and many employees stay for their entire careers.
cons:
Our department had three directors in six years and none of them tried to get to know us. 
You earn ample vacation hours at Stanford, but you are required to use a large chunk of it when the university has a mandatory shut down in December.

review_title: Excellent place to work; smart, respectful
job_title: Lab Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Flexibility of scheduling, extremely good management interaction, excellent people and co-workers, great benefits, reasonably compensation, excellent hiring practices, terrific environment
cons: It is a bit tough to advance within certain departments; if you are employed within a scientific department, you may be locked to a single position, and advancing will mean leaving.

review_title: I love my job but can't stand the administrators.
pros: Prestigious name, beautiful campus & facilities, decent benefits.
cons: Mediocre pay, VERY political, little or no respect for long-time employees.  Administrators are more concerned with covering their rears and impressing superiors than they are about doing the right  things.  HR is a joke.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work for, with a few caveats to be aware of
pros: Stanford has incredible resources and uses these to support their faculty, staff, and students. They also do a wonderful job of fostering an accepting, caring community among university members.
cons: The working environment can be pretty daunting and the expectations and workload are sometimes unreasonable. Also, the individuals here, while well-intentioned, are not necessarily the most earthly or exciting people to socialize with.

pros: Good access to professors and great career development. You get paid to help teach your peers which is awesome and makes you a better student yourself.
cons: I don't think there are many. Pay for undergrad TAs is a little low, but the opportunities are endless. Really like it here.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros:
Great location (except cost of living) if you like to bike ride to work. It's a great part of California, close to the ocean and with a lot on offer around the bay too.
Stanford is so big it makes little sense to review for management etc - it varies by department so take this with a grain of salt.
cons: High cost of housing. That is it.

job_title: IT Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great support and upward mobility, outstanding benefits, generous leave upon hire. Stanford stands behind the work life balance as well it's not just words on a website. All my managers were very supportive of continuing education. Biggest benefit was health coverage and winter school closure.
cons: Living in the bay area, dealing with the commute time, traffic and semi predictable Cal-Train. Also the cost of living in the area is not on par with the rest of the US.

pros:
Good benefits 
Flexible hours 
Great campus - lot of energy on the campus
Good work-life balance
As a staff member, you can attend events, classes on campus
cons:
Nepotism is rampant, not only at the Libraries but in most Staff jobs
Surprisingly, technically inept
Very strong pattern of intolerance of competence

pros: Good hardware layout. Very good benefits. Working in such a a high-reputation university is of some good feeling. The libraries and golf courses are world-class.
cons: My advisor never pays attentionto my work. The research often deviates too much from practical use. The working style is lazy and slack.

pros: The co-workers are amazing. There is a great collaborative workplace culture with always something new to learn and interesting professional development activities going on. The  company benefits are quite comprehensive and include on-site access to fitness facilities. There is a strong support of work-life balance. Great public transit access in place with additional incentives for commuters.
cons: Department goals can be presented better at times to promote employee buy-in at the junior levels and discourage workplace politics.

review_title: The value of Stanford's Graduate School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford is very well-connected.  Being part of Stanford allows you to experience many interactions that are only possible in few places in the world.  People takes your work more seriously, so cherish that opportunity and make the best of it.
cons: With great power comes great responsibility.  People here works hard, so you are expected to do the same.  Prepare to do anything necessary to make your project a success.

pros: Stanford is brimming with smart, interesting and talented people. I've had so many rich conversations and made lasting friendships with the people I've met there. Many opportunities to learn with an abundance of excellent lectures and seminar series across all disciplines in the university. Campus is gorgeous.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work at

review_title: Stanford is great for security nothing else
pros: Great benefits, but there's a caveat
cons:
Stanford is a great place if you're looking for security. But, you’ll hate yourself in the long-term for sacrificing your motivation and desire to challenge yourself and grow if you stay here.

If you're looking for professional growth, it is not the place. If you're looking for a great income, it is not the place. If you're looking to have an impact with your creativity, it is not the place. If you’re looking to make a decent yet lower-than SF Bay Area wage while having great security, it is that place. 

This is how you may get screwed. On one hand, Stanford tells you that since you have amazing benefits, your salary can't be too high. Then they wonder why the turnover rate is insane. Once you begin and learn that the previous person was making a lot more than you, you automatically begin to shut-down. Your performance plummets and you begin running like a rabbit to get the hell out of there. They're simply not direct or honest in their hiring process. The salary range they provide (if they still do that, I haven’t been a part of Stanford for sometime), is extremely misleading. Whatever job you take, expect your salary to be on the very low-end of that scale. Also, expect whatever job you take to be directly affected by your previous position. If you went from a gardner to a Doctor, Stanford HR will insist to pay you based on your gardening income. This hardly happens, but you get the picture. 

If you're making salary X, it will be below market. Why? They tell you that your benefits account for an additional 30% of "income." Well, OK that sounds great right? Then if you were to get that same position as an hourly staff, do you think they would pay you your original hourly income plus that 30%? Dream on. They will tell you that what you're making per hour is too high. You'll most likely make your annual salary's hourly rate even when you have no benefits. This way, they pay their full-times employees little by telling them they have great benefits and also keep their hourly employees with low wages by touting their "high" hourly wages. 

Most of the benefits are accounting tricks. They say you get X value of benefits, when they probably pay a tenth of that to the benefit provider. So, they screw you over and still expect you to thank them. They’re not hiring idiots, but they treat you like one.

Example: You're making 100k with benefits. 100k comes out to ~$50 per hour. Uncle Sam, takes around ~35% (maybe more depending on your circumstance). So, you're actual hourly rate is around $37. With Stanford's benefits, that's not a bad deal at all assuming that you're getting paid the right salary for that job. But, you'll likely make $70k ($35/hour) at Stanford because they inflate benefits. The $35/hour after taxes is around $25/hour. So you just lost over $10 per hour because of the way they calculate your salary. 

So, you decide why not work strictly as an hourly employee? I'll at least make more per hour since they'll use the same calculation to add the 30% of benefits to my hourly income right? Wrong. If you were hired as hourly, you may be lucky to earn $40/hour without benefits for a job with $35 with benefits that should actually pay $50/hour. You ask them, wait a second what about the fact that this job has no benefits? They tell you that the typical hourly of a similar position is $35 (They don’t mention benefits) and you're getting overpaid at $40/hour. 

Basically, when it benefits them to include benefits so they don't have to pay full-time employees well, they do. When it benefits them to solely focus on your hourly to pay their hourly employees little, they do the same. 

As someone else already mentioned, this is a great place to learn, grow and move on (either to a higher position at Stanford or another place). If you decide to stay complacent and stay in the same position for more than two years, you'll hate yourself forever. 

Don't buy into the idea that Stanford is an educational non-profit. IAnyone who has worked here knows how much the university spends on Palm Trees and how much they shell out for their execs.

pros: Great community of interesting, excited people. The scientists, researchers, and students are heroicly dedicated and collaborative

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA

review_title: I am a graduate student doing research in a lab

review_title: Nice place to work if you are a faculty member.
job_title: Program Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Stanford offers an intellectually stimulating atmosphere, a beautiful campus, an ethnically diverse workforce, and an extensive support structure for faculty. Salaries are competitive in most job areas, though the cost of living in the bay area offsets this somewhat. 

Although promotion within one's department can be slow, the university's many and varied academic and administrative departments offer chances for advancement in the larger organization. Professional growth is actively encouraged through a variety of training opportunities and funds. 

Like most universities, Stanford offers a generous vacation package. Exempt staff receive three weeks to start and four weeks after one year; most non-exempt employees receive two weeks to start and advance to three weeks. Personal days and a basic allotment of holidays add up. The university is also developing flexible work schedules to attract and retain administrative staff.

The university is a leader in alternative transportation, including free access to Caltrain and VTA, carpool parking discounts, on-campus access to daily and hourly car rentals, cash incentives, and free local shuttle buses. On-campus parking is limited and expensive (see next section).

And don't forget the fabulous weather!
cons:
Stanford is a feudal society. The Crown (senior academic officers) flourish in a rarified atmosphere of privilege and pomp. The nobility (faculty) also enjoy extensive privilege and, depending upon what fiefdom they inhabit, are well paid and accommodated. Vassals (exempt administrative staff) and peasants (non-exempt support staff) are treated like servants -- expensive, but necessary., nuisances. 

Employee benefits are generally competitive, however they are gradually eroding as Stanford becomes more and more corporate and seeks costs savings in these areas. E.g., promised retiree healthcare benefits were recently reduced for non-vested staff, employee training funds were cut by one third, and layoffs have become routine. Faculty are favored, with housing stipends and other programs not enjoyed by administrative and support staff.

Plans exist to move as many administrative staff as possible off campus, effectively removing one of the most attractive reasons to work at Stanford. A number of departments have already been moved to an office park and many more will be moved to similar quarters in surrounding communities over the next several years.

Paid parking permits are required during normal working hours. Permits are expensive and parking can be scarce and inconveniently located. However, the university promotes and sponsors an excellent alternative transportation system (see previous section).

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros:
Intelligent and hard-working people everywhere, challenging and exciting research, all the infrastructure one could wish for.
Beautiful campus, wonderful weather :)
Having the Stanford background raises the bar for everything you will do afterwards. If you get the chance, just do it!
cons: Low pay, could not afford their health insurance (over $2000 per month for a family!). Cost of living in the area is high.

review_title: Recent college grad but no more than 2 years.
pros:
Worked here several years ago and my experience was the worst. I wish I was out of work instead of having worked here and I finally decided to write a review.

It's at an elite university and great compensation as part of Stanford University. You may make a difference by your presence but because it's a committee process everyone will second guess you at every turn and you'll leave a cycle feeling like your perspective and voice is meaningless.
cons:
Management treats employees like children, overly focused on small mistakes while completely ignoring dedication and passion. They don't care if you kill yourself for this job. 

Admission is a tough field. As an incoming counselor you'll make 50k at best and while that is great for a first job, keep in mind that the number of applications that Stanford receives is close to 40k now and during the regular decision cycle you'll be working everyday including weekends. Expect to have 0 life from November all the way through April when we have admit weekend. That means expect no sick days or emergency time off because you're treated like you don't value your work. 

You're made to feel dispensable and you'd think that considering the level of turnover they'd care a little about keeping people around. The name of admission counselors is listed and if you keep track I guarantee you that every other year at least 80% of the staff is gone.  And you don't think that affects the quality of the work? 

Get into admission as a starting job, but keep in mind that you'll learn everything in about a year and the rest is doing repetitive tasks from year to year to year. Unless you really care about admission the management, being overworked, and overall  unfulfilled sense will take over.

The longer you stay the worse you'll be treated. I think they'd rather get rid of people and pay the new employees even lower salaries, starting salary of older employees, than retain them. There's little in-office mobility (not new to Stanford) in admission.

review_title: Underpaid, misinterpreted, and terrible bosses with a lack of leadership skills and toxic culture is encouraged
job_title: Staff Accountant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, there are a few nice people to work with. Public transit is paid for, and free shuttle service to campus.
cons: The culture is toxic and people are encouraged to not work as a team. I had a very gossipy boss. She acts sweet and she kisses up to her bosses all the time. If you make a tiny, non-life threatening error she was quick to blame you. The supervisors also do not listen to you if you have a suggestion to improve efficiency. While working at Stanford, I wanted to help improve a process by setting up a friendly meeting with the business partners. At the meeting we discussed what could be improved, but after my meeting my boss told me I was stepping out of line and she was furious with me. Additionally, my boss had the audacity to even criticize my personal life and my situation (when I really did not share much with her). Though she may argue she is being "honest" her comments has no place in a professional environment. She even turned her employees against each other. When I was a contractor I was once stupid enough to believe her. To add insult to injury the head of the department makes a ton of money, but shares none of it with his employees. In fact every year, I would receive a note from Stanford that my pay is below the poverty level and qualifies for additional tax credits. Even the bonuses and the raises (if you get any) are cheap. I only received a lousy bonus of $500 with 60% of it eaten by taxes. I worked my tail off as I was doing the job of two people with no one available to help me despite having the time and resources. Run from this job don't walk or get out as fast as you can your pay will never improve. Supervisors are more worried about their own hides than your professional development, your wellbeing, or growth.

review_title: A serious career and financial setback in exchange for a name that no one cares about
pros: There is an abundance of high technology and opportunities to work on cutting-edge projects.
cons:
1) Academic salaries are far below the range of academic peers when the cost of living is factored in. Postdoc salaries are traditionally lower than many unionized manual labor employees at Stanford. Postdoc and Junior faculty salaries are typically not sufficient to obtain affordable single housing whilst not being "rent-burdened" (>30% of gross salary going to rent). Postdocs are currently paid $63,700 ($5,308/month). In order to not be rent-burdened, one must obtain housing for less than $1592/month. 1 bedroom rentals in the bay area are $2,500-3,000/month. Stanfords own 1 bedroom apartments which are "below market" rent for $2,763-$3545 (as of May 2020). A Salary in excess of $110K is required to not be rent-burdened in below-market-rate housing. To work at Stanford is to lose $1,000-$1,500 a month compared to a similar position almost anywhere else. 

 2) People don't matter. The big theme I have noticed is that people and relationships are disposable commodities. The things that are important are resources, money, control, and prestige. People can be exploited, disposed of, used, and mistreated in pursuit of those priorities because people can always be replaced at Stanford. The general operating procedure is to exploit the innovative thinking of a wide base of disposable postdocs and non-tenure line, soft-money junior faculty members. This pattern leads to aspiring permanent faculty members jockeying to exploit each other and trainees for artificially scarce resources. Those that are the best at exploiting others rise to the top and vicious cycle. This exploitation dynamic often creates work situations that qualify as toxic workplaces. I estimate approximately 30% of my working time at Stanford is consumed by defending against political maneuvering aimed at seizing resources, labor, products, or credit for the things and ideas that I have generated. That is far too much.

3) Researchers (that do not also provide clinical services) do not achieve regular faculty positions. The have non-faculty titles like "instructor" which anywhere else would be an Assitant Professor level position. The funding levels required for a permanent position is the equivalent of 2.5 R01 level grants ( a total of $17M every 5 years), in perpetuity. The average age of a scientist receiving their first R01 is 43. So this standard is beyond extremely difficult. The medical school does not actually pay researchers' a salary. The researchers have to pay 100% of their own salary from the grants they receive (100% soft money). If you can not raise 100% of your salary you are fired or reduce your working hours to match the grant money you have. 56% of the funding from these grants goes to support institutional administrative costs. Administrators do not have to raise money for their own salaries. There are many many more administrators that researchers. 

4) The Stanford name isn't that helpful. People that work at Stanford think that having the Stanford name on their resume/CV is a big bonus for obtaining their next job. From my experience so far it really isn't that helpful. People often recognize the name but the name will not be the thing that will determine if you get your next job. The name is certainly not worth what you give up in terms of money and speed of career advancement.

review_title: Suddenly Going Dumb or I have worked my butt off for over 20 years to be treated like a sub human!

cons: The management - Petty, picky, incompetent and if you didn't side with them then your career was dead!  When the supervisor and manager are best buds and they only give one day training and then expect you to run the office while they go out and have playmates with the students..Good Luck!  They make your 20 years of hard work as an admin suddenly seem like you should apply for disability.  Some managers on campus even make you write a report on a daily basis to tell them how many transactions you have completed, how many are still on your plate and what your goals will be the following day.  Remember to cross your "t's" and dot your "i's" because you will be written up if you don't or just wait until you are fired and notice that your termination letter is filled with misspellings!

pros:
You help to educate about 40,000 K-7 students in Mathmatics.  Many of the older employees care very much about this and have become quite qualified over the years.  They're "true believers" in education, and if you're one too, you'll have plenty of friends.

Central Stanford has good benefits, organization, and training oppourtunities.  Thanks to a brilliant head of programming, the technologies running the software that students and teachers use is quite sophisticated.  It's a good place to learn many technologies if you're an engineer, though you'll have to deal with a lot of legacy.
cons:
Salaries are only about 60% of what similar positions are payed within other departments of the university.  Salaries are dramatically low, which leads to high turnover and an inability to fill desperately needed positions, often for half a year or more, since almost no one is willing to work for so little.  Often offices and promotions that properly belong with more far more experienced people who have been at the company for many years are lost as perks to attract people into new positions.

A middle-management layer was recently introduced as the group got larger, however these were a mixed bag mostly from much larger companies and most of their styles clash badly with the software / process we actually have.  Differing opinions of how to proceed on projects were hard enough to reconcile years ago, and the clash has exacerbated that.  There's definitely a lot of cultural shear as the older academics and engineers are being displaced and driven away by generic non-technical business people.

The software and processes have a technical complexity at this point that's beyond the technical understanding of the head of the organization, almost all of the middle management, and about two-thirds of the ground-level employees.
